questions.text: Which of the following is used in the management of tumor lysis syndrome?
questions.solution:
Rasburicase, a recombinant urate oxidase is used in the management of tumor lysis syndrome (TLS). TLS is associated with hyperuricemia and rasburicase helps in decreasing the levels of uric acid in the blood.

Management of TLS includes:

  • Aggressive hydration
  • Allopurinol
  • Urinary alkalinization with sodium bicarbonate (controversial)
  • Rasburicase - recombinant urate oxidase.

However, rituximab, gemtuzumab, and alemtuzumab are monoclonal antibodies that cause a rapid fall in circulating tumor cells upon infusion and may lead to TLS.

questions.text: A gross specimen of the colon obtained from a 14-year-old boy is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The gross specimen in the image shows the presence of multiple polyps in the colon suggestive of familial adenomatous polyposis.

Familial adenomatous polyposis is an autosomal dominant disease that usually occurs in teenagers

  • It is caused by mutations in the APC gene, which is a key negative regulator in the WNT signaling pathway
  • 75% of the cases are inherited and a few are sporadic
  • The polyps are morphologically indistinguishable from sporadic adenomas. The gross appearance will be a sessile or pedunculated mass between 0.3 to 10 cm in diameter. The texture will be velvet or raspberry. Histologically, the hallmark of epithelial dysplasia is nuclear hyperchromasia, elongation, and stratification. They can be classified as tubular, villous, or tubulovillous based on architecture
  • Colorectal carcinoma occurs in 100% of cases before the age of 50. 
  • Prophylactic colectomy is recommended in patients with APC gene mutations.
  • At least 100 polyps are required to make a diagnosis of familial adenomatous polyposis.

Related Pearl: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

Gastrointestinal manifestations:

  • Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyp usually >100
  • Gastric and duodenal polyps are present in 50% cases.
  • Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma.
  • Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) seen in 75% of cases; it is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Desmoid tumors in the abdomen
  • Osteoma: In the skull, mandible, and tibia
  • Brain tumors
  • Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

questions.text: Which of the following side effects are seen most commonly with Isotretinoin (13-cis-retinoic acid)?
questions.solution:
Embryopathy is the most common side effect seen with isotretinoin.

Isotretinoin is a vitamin A derivative that is highly teratogenic when orally administered. It is commonly used to treat cystic nodular acne. It inhibits the migration of neural crest cells during embryogenesis and affects the development of multiple organs. These defects are collectively termed retinoic acid embryopathy.

Specific anomalies may include ventriculomegaly, maldevelopment of the facial bones or cranium, microtia or anotia, micrognathia, cleft palate, conotruncal heart defects, and thymic aplasia or hypoplasia.

Isotretinoin also increases the risk of spontaneous abortions and stillbirths by up to 40% in pregnancies exposed in the first quarter of this medicine. Presenting with pregnancy during treatment with isotretinoin is a failure of prevention strategies.

The guidelines for isotretinoin usage are as follows:

  • Isotretinoin is a teratogenic drug that should not be taken during pregnancy and nursing
  • Patients should take 2 pregnancy tests before starting isotretinoin and take a monthly pregnancy test while on the medication, and another test 1 month after stopping the medication.
  • Two forms of birth control should be simultaneously used starting 1 month before treatment, during the entire course of treatment, and for 1 month after ceasing treatment with isotretinoin.
  • Isotretinoin should be reserved for the treatment of severe, nodulocystic acne and should not be used for milder forms of acne.

Other options:

Option B: Lithium is used in the treatment of bipolar disorder. It is a teratogen associated with Ebstein's anomaly which is a rare cardiac condition characterized by severe tricuspid regurgitation and right atrial enlargement.

Option C: Valproic acid is the anti-epileptic which confers the greatest risk to the developing fetus while used in pregnancy. It is associated with an increased risk of neural tube defects in the fetus.

Option D: Tetracyclines are associated with yellowish-brown discoloration of deciduous teeth when used after 25 weeks of gestation.

questions.solution:
The given image shows placenta previa.

The grades of placenta previa are:

  • Type I (Low-lying): The major part of the placenta is attached to the upper segment and only the
    lower margin encroaches onto the lower segment but not up to the os.
  • Type II (Marginal): The placenta reaches the margin of the internal os but does not cover it.
  • Type III (Incomplete or partial central): The placenta covers the internal os partially (covers the
    internal os when closed but does not entirely do so when fully dilated).
  • Type IV (Central or total): The placenta completely covers the internal os even after it is fully dilated.

questions.text: Oligohydramnios is associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Oligohydramnios is associated with renal agenesis.

Oligohydramnios is a condition where the liquor amnii is deficient in an amount to the extent of less than 200mL at term.

Sonographically, it is defined when the maximum vertical pocket of liquor is less than <2 cm or when amniotic fluid index (AFI) is less than 5 cm (less than 5 percentile).

Fetal urine production begins between 8-11 weeks but it does not become a major component of amniotic fluid until the 2nd trimester and is the major part of amniotic fluid after 20 weeks. In a case of renal agenesis, there is decreased or no urine output leading to oligohydramnios, which does not manifest till after 18 weeks.

Etiology of oligohydramnios:

  • Placental condition:
    • Amnion nodosum (failure of secretion by the cells of the amnion covering the placenta).
  • Fetal conditions:
    • Fetal chromosomal or structural anomalies
    • Renal agenesis
    • Obstructed uropathy
    • Spontaneous rupture of membrane
    • Intrauterine infection
    • Drugs (PG inhibitors, ACE inhibitors)
    • Post maturity
    • IUGR
  • Maternal conditions:
    • Hypertensive disorders
    • Uteroplacental insufficiency
    • Dehydration
    • Idiopathic

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with headache, vomiting, amenorrhea, galactorrhea, loss of libido, acromegaly, and infertility. On examination, she has bitemporal hemianopia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The symptoms are suggestive of a local mass effect on the pituitary. The most likely diagnosis is a mammosomatotrope adenoma of the pituitary in which excess prolactin and growth hormone are seen.

 Important points about pituitary adenomas

  • G ­protein mutations (particularly GNAS) are the most common genetic alterations seen in pituitary adenomas.
  • Pituitary adenomas are usually found in adults.
  • They may be functioning or non-functioning.
  • They are called microadenomas if they are <1 cm in diameter and macroadenomas if they are >1 cm in diameter.
  • Cellular monomorphism and the absence of a significant reticulin network distinguish pituitary adenomas from nonneoplastic anterior pituitary parenchyma.

Prolactinoma:

  • Prolactin-secreting lactotroph adenomas are the most frequent type of hyperfunctioning pituitary adenomas.
  • Females Males 
    Galactorrhoea

    galactorrhoea

    Gynecomastia
    Amenorrhoea or oligomenorrhoea Loss of libido
    Infertility

    Impotence 

    infertility
  • Serum prolactin concentrations tend to correlate with the size of the adenoma.

  • The normal range of serum prolactin is 5-20 μg/L. The diagnosis of prolactinoma is most likely to be associated with a prolactin level >200 μg/L.

 

Acromegaly:

Acromegaly occurs when excessive GH is secreted after puberty (after fusion of long bone epiphysis). Features include acral bony overgrowth resulting in frontal bossing, mandibular enlargement with prognathism, increased heel pad thickness, increased shoe or glove size, ring tightening, characteristic coarse facial features, and a large fleshy nose. 

Serious effects include cardiomyopathy with arrhythmias, diabetes mellitus, obstructive sleep apnoea, and increased risk of colonic polyps and cancer. Age-matched IGF-I levels are elevated. 

If excessive GH is secreted before puberty, gigantism results.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient, an accident victim started developing difficulty in breathing. On examination, his BP was 80/40mmHg and pulses were feeble, JVP was found to be elevated with an absent y descent, and heart sounds were muffled. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and elevated JVP -  Beck's triad suggests a diagnosis of cardiac tamponade. The JVP finding most likely to be seen is prominent x descent and absent y descent.

Cardiac tamponade is the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space. It results in the obstruction of the blood flow into the ventricles.

This manifests as Beck's triad which consists of the following: 

  • Distended neck veins (due to decreased venous return)
  • Muffled heart sounds (fluid accumulation in the pericardial space)
  • Hypotension

The physical examination findings in a patient with cardiac tamponade are:

  • Tachycardia
  • Hypotension
  • Elevated JVP
  • Pulsus paradoxus

The chest wall movements will be normal. An eFAST is reliable and will show fluid in the pericardial space. A chest X-ray will show an enlarged heart shadow.

Cardiac tamponade can also be treated with open surgery procedures like sternotomy or left thoracotomy. This also allows for the heart to be repaired during the procedure.

questions.text: Vitamin K supplementation is given to neonates to prevent ___.
questions.solution:
Intramuscular injection of 0.5-1 mg of phytonadione (vitamin K)  is given to all newborn infants to prevent hemorrhagic disease of the newborn. 

Hemorrhagic disease of the newborn is caused by a transient deficiency of vitamin K–dependent factors, factors II, VII, IX, and X.

Causes include:

  • Lack of free vitamin K from the mother
  • Absence of the bacterial intestinal flora normally responsible for the synthesis of vitamin K.

It is responsive to and prevented by vitamin K therapy (0.5-1 mg of phytonadione).

However, for newborns with vitamin K deficiency, the dose of vitamin K administered is 1–5 mg intravenously.

questions.text: Prophylactic cranial irradiation is given for which of the following cancers?
questions.solution:
Prophylactic cranial irradiation is given in lung cancer, more specifically small cell carcinoma of lung.

Prophylactic cranial irradiation(PCI) is given to  either LD-SCLC(limited disease small cell lung carcinoma) or ED-SCLC(end stage small cell lung carcinoma) who have responded well to initial therapy.

In LD-SCLC patients complete remission is seen while in ED-SCLC the occurence of symptomatic brain metastases is decreased and prolonged disease free interval compared to when no PCI.

Small-cell carcinoma of the lung is the most aggressive type of lung cancer.

This tumor originates from neuroendocrine progenitor cells (Kulchitsky cells), which are present in the lining bronchial epithelium.

questions.text: A 46-year-old chronic alcoholic male presents to the OPD with fever, headache, shortness of breath, chest pain,  and productive cough for the last two days. On examination, there was bronchial breathing on the right side, increased vocal fremitus, increased vocal resonance, and a dull note on percussion. The patient's plain radiograph is shown below. Which is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with patient having symptoms of  fever, headache, shortness of breath, chest pain,  and productive cough with the chest x-ray showing a bulging fissure sign is highly suggestive of lobar pneumonia The likely causative organism is Klebsiella pneumoniae.

Klebsiella pneumonia is associated mostly with alcoholics and shows upper lobe involvement, cavitation, and pneumatocele (also seen in S. aureus). The patient presents with red currant-jelly sputum. A bulging fissure sign is classically seen in Klebsiella pneumonia. It represents expansive lobar consolidation causing fissural bulging or displacement by copious amounts of inflammatory exudate within the affected parenchyma. Classically, it is associated with right upper lobe consolidation due to Klebsiella pneumonia. Other diseases that manifest a bulging fissure include any space-occupying process in the lung, such as pulmonary hemorrhage, lung abscess, and tumor.

Classic chest X-ray findings include:

  • Upper lobe consolidation - classically on the right side.
  • Cavitation
  • Bulging fissure sign - expansive lobar consolidation and inflammatory exudates cause the lower border of the upper lobe to bulge. It can also be seen with space-occupying lesions of the lung, such as pulmonary hemorrhage, lung abscess, and tumor.


The following image shows bulging fissure sign. 

Broad-spectrum antibiotics should be used for treatment and include third-generation cephalosporins and beta-lactam antibiotics with beta-lactamase inhibitors. Nosocomial infection with Klebsiella is difficult to treat in many situations as they produce extended-spectrum beta-lactamase and are resistant to many antibiotics.

Other options:

Option A : Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common causative agent of community-acquired pneumonia.

Option C : Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive, non-lactose fermenting bacteria that shows swarming motility. Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa include, Burns infections, Opportunistic and nosocomial infections, Pneumonia in cystic fibrosis, Shanghai fever(severe enteric disease and sepsis), Malignant otitis externa in diabetics, Jacuzzi syndrome (Hot tub folliculitis),Ecthyma gangrenosum, Green-nail syndrome.

Option D : Haemophilus influenzae is a gram-negative, non-motile, and non-sporing coccobacillus. H.influenzae causes meningitis, a potentially fatal disease that is most common in children of two months to 3 years old. It also causes laryngo-epiglottitis, pneumonia, suppurative lesions, and bronchitis.

questions.text: Identify the deformity depicted in the image.
questions.solution:
The image shows flexion of the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint with hyperextension of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint. This deformity is known as Boutonnière deformity seen in rheumatoid arthritis.

 Rheumatoid Arthritis :

It is a chronic inflammatory disease. Its incidence increases between 25 and 55 years of age.

Signs and symptoms -

  • Swelling and pain of the small joints of the hands initially(spares DIP joint)
  • Morning stiffness
  • Swan-neck deformity(hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint), Boutonnière deformity(flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint), or Z-line deformity(subluxation of the first MCP joint with hyperextension of the first interphalangeal (IP) joint )
  • Ulnar deviation of fingers
  • Constitutional findings such as fever, weight loss, etc
  • Monoarthritis of large joints can occur later
  • Tenosynovitis of palm(trigger finger0
  • Atlantoaxial joint involvement

Joints commonly affected in Rheumatoid Arthritis: (bilateral and symmetrically involved) 

  • MCP joints
  • Wrists
  • PIP joints
  • MTP joints
  • Atlantoaxial joint

Diagnosis is made with clinical signs and symptoms with corroboration from lab and imaging findings.

Anti-CCP, RF, and synovial fluid analysis are important lab investigations.

X-ray findings show -
soft tissue swelling, joint space narrowing, periarticular osteopenia, and bony erosions

Treatment of rheumatoid arthritis (RA)

DMARDs (Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs) are the mainstay of treatment.

Methotrexate is the drug of choice in patients with RA. It can be used alone (in low disease activity) or with a 3-drug combination (in high disease activity) with other DMARDs such as hydroxychloroquine, sulfasalazine, and leflunomide (reserve drug).

  • It is a folic acid analong
  • Inhibits dihydrofolate reductase
  • Causes reversible myelosuppression
  • Leucovorin is used to manage myelosuppression
  • Can cause pulmonary fibrosis
  • Escalation with triple therapy involves - methotrexate + sulfasalazine + hydroxychloroquine
  • Glucocorticoids 

Other extra-articular manifestations are:

  • Sjogren's syndrome
  • Pericarditis, Mitral regurgitation
  • Pleuritis, Interstitial Lung disease
  • Vasculitis
  • Felty's syndrome
  • Diffuse large B cell lymphoma

questions.text: A patient stopped alcohol consumption for 3 days and presented with irritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, agitation, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient who has not consumed alcohol for the past 3 days with disorientation, paranoid delusions, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium is suggestive of delirium tremens.

Delirium tremens is a medical emergency that occurs during alcohol withdrawal. It is an acute condition and usually develops within 72 hours after the last drink. It has symptoms of both delirium and alcohol withdrawal. The clinical features of delirium tremens are:

  • Altered sensorium with disorientation
  • Perceptual distortions, most frequently tactile or visual hallucinations
  • Autonomic hyperactivity with tachycardia, fever, anxiety, insomnia, hypertension. And sweating
  • Fluctuating levels of psychomotor activity, ranging from agitation to lethargy
  • Altered sleep-wake cycle

Other options:

Option B: Wernicke’s encephalopathy (alcoholic encephalopathy) is associated with thiamine deficiency. Alcohol abuse may lead to thiamine deficiency because of poor nutritional habits, or malabsorption. It is an acute neurological disorder characterized by:

  • Global confusion
  • Ocular abnormalities like horizontal nystagmus, gaze palsy, anisocoria, and sluggish pupillary reflex
  • Ataxia - mainly affecting the gait
  • Vestibular dysfunction

It may resolve with thiamine therapy or progress to Korsakoff's syndrome.

Option C: Korsakoff’s psychosis can follow Wernicke’s encephalopathy due to thiamine deficiency. It is a chronic amnestic syndrome that is characterized by the following clinical symptoms in an intact and responsive patient:

  • Impaired mental syndrome, especially recent memory
  • Anterograde amnesia
  • Confabulation

Option D: Alcohol-induced psychosis is characterized by the development of auditory hallucinations or paranoid delusions in the context of heavy drinking or alcohol withdrawal. These patients have a clear sensorium, unlike the patients having delirium tremens.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with recurrent episodes of chest pain which is seen only on exertion or exercise and lasts 2-5 minutes. He was assessed and was diagnosed with a case of stable angina however his blood pressure was consistently elevated. What is the most appropriate antihypertensive for this patient?
questions.solution:
The antihypertensive drug of choice in stable angina is beta-blockers which is atenolol here.

Atenolol is a cardioselective beta-blocker that works by decreasing cardiac contractility and heart rate which decreases cardiac output and blood pressure.

Beta-blockers are also used in congestive cardiac failure which has been shown to decrease their mortality rates.

Stable angina:

  • Stable angina is caused by an imbalance in coronary perfusion (due to chronic stenosing coronary atherosclerosis) relative to myocardial demand.
  • Squeezing, central, substernal discomfort
  • Crescendo-decrescendo in nature
  • Typically lasts 2 to 5 min
  • Can radiate to either shoulder & to both arms (especially the ulnar surfaces of the forearm & hand)
  • It also can arise in or radiate to the back, interscapular region, the root of the neck, jaw, teeth, and epigastrium.

Other types of angina

  • Prinzmetal variant angina is an uncommon form of episodic myocardial ischemia; it is caused by coronary artery spasm.
  • Unstable or crescendo angina refers to a pattern of increasingly frequent, prolonged (>20 min), or severe angina or chest discomfort that is described as frank pain, precipitated by progressively lower levels of physical activity or even occurring at rest.

Related Pearl: Anti-anginal drugs

Anti-anginal drugs can be divided into the following categories:

  • Nitrates - Dilates veins > arteries. Reduces preload.
  • Calcium channel blockers - Blocks L-type calcium channels
    • Dihydropyridines - Amlodipine, nifedipine
    • Non-dihydropyridines - Verapamil, Diltiazem
  • Beta-blockers - Decreases heart rate, contractility and oxygen demand
  • Other drugs 
    • Ranolazine - Late Na+ channel blocker
    • Ivabradine - Inhibit funny currents in SA node
    • Nicorandil - K+-ATP channel agonist
    • Trimetazidine - pFOX inhibitor
    • Fasudil - Rho-kinase inhibitor

questions.text: Identify the investigation shown below.
questions.solution:
The investigation shown above is enteroclysis.

Enteroclysis is a barium study in which the contrast agent is put directly into the duodenum through a nasogastric tube.

Continued infusion of 500 to 1000 mL of thin barium sulfate and methylcellulose suspension is done and then viewed continuously with the use of either fluoroscopy or radiographs taken at frequent intervals. This technique is a double-contrast procedure that allows detailed imaging of the entire small intestine.

Enteroclysis has a sensitivity of over 90% in the detection of small bowel tumors (Particularly for tumors located in the distal small bowel) and is the investigation of choice in low-grade, intermittent small bowel obstruction.

Advantages of enteroclysis:

  • The contrast is administered at a controlled rate directly in the small bowel, bypassing the regulatory action of the pylorus.
  • The entire small bowel is demonstrated in a distended state, allowing better diagnosis. As a result of the dilatation, the following can be visualized:
    • Mild strictures
    • Small sinus tracts and fistulas
    • Minimal extrinsic compressions
    • Skip lesions
    • Proximal and distal extent of diffuse diseases.
  • The examination can be completed in 15–30 minutes, thus reducing patient waiting time.

Other options:

Option B: Barium meal assesses the stomach and duodenum (95% BaSO4 is used). Used in ulcers, small fleshy lumps (polyps), and tumours.

Option C: Barium meal follow-through is used to assess the small intestine (50% BaSO4 is used). It is performed following a barium meal examination where X-rays are taken 10-15 minutes after barium intake. This allows time for the barium to reach the small intestine. 

Option D: Barium swallow is used to assess the pharynx, oesophagus, and stomach. (Barium paste is used). They are used in hiatus hernias, tumours, reflux from the stomach, and disorders of swallowing.

questions.text:
An elderly woman presented with symptoms of confusion, thirst, and abdominal pain. On examination, she had pallor and thoracic spine tenderness. Her lab investigations showed the following findings. An X-ray of her skull is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
  • Hb - 6.9g/dL
  • WBC 4000/cm3 with normal differential count
  • Serum calcium 13mg/dL
  • Creatinine 2.3mg/dL
  • Total protein 9g/dL
  • Albumin 2.4g/dL
  • Urinalysis: positive for Bence-Jones proteins
questions.solution:
The given clinical features along with hypercalcemia, elevated creatinine suggestive of renal failure, anemia, osteolytic bone lesions (CRAB features), hypoalbuminemia with elevated total proteins, and Bence Jones proteinuria make multiple myeloma the most likely diagnosis.

Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia with the proliferation of plasma cells derived from a single clone. It is associated with increased osteoclast activity with suppression of osteoblast activity, causing punched-out lytic lesions in the bone and hypercalcemia.

Signs and symptoms

  • Bone pain is the most common symptom
  • Pathologic fractures
  • Recurrent bacterial infections
  • Renal failure
  • Normocytic normochromic anemia elevated ESR, Hypercalcemia, normal ALP (ALP is a marker of bone growth and hence is not increased in multiple myeloma)
  • Radiography: Punched-out lytic lesions on X-ray
  • Electrophoresis: Monoclonal elevation of one immunoglobulin
  • Urinalysis: Free kappa and lambda light chains (Bence Jones proteins)
  • Bone marrow biopsy: 10 to 20% plasma cells (normal is < 5%)
  • Peripheral smear: Rouleaux formation (High level of M proteins in myeloma causes red cells in the peripheral blood smears to stick to one another in linear arrays, a finding referred to as rouleaux formation)

Revised International Myeloma Working Group criteria for the diagnosis of multiple myeloma:

Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥10% (or) Biopsy-proven bony or extramedullary plasmacytoma

Plus

Any one or more of the following myeloma-defining events:

  • Evidence of end-organ damage attributable to the underlying plasma cell proliferative disorder, specifically:(CRAB features)
    • HyperCalcemia: Serum calcium level >1 mg/dL higher than the upper limit of normal or >11 mg/dL
    • Renal insufficiency: Creatinine clearance <40 mL/min or serum creatinine >2 mg/dL
    • Anemia: Hemoglobin level of >20 g/L (2gm/dl) below the lowest limit of normal, or Hb <10 g/dL
    • Bone lesions: One or more osteolytic lesions on skeletal radiography, computed tomography (CT), or positron emission tomography (PET)/CT.
  • Any one or more of the following biomarkers of malignancy:
    • Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥60%
    • Serum involved/uninvolved free light-chain ratio of 100 or greater
    • >1 focal lesion on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) that is at least 5 mm or greater in size.

Note:

  • The presence of at least one of these markers is considered sufficient for a diagnosis of multiple myeloma, regardless of the presence or absence of symptoms or CRAB features.
  • Each of these markers has been shown to be associated with an approximately 80% or higher risk of developing myeloma-related organ damage within two years.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female with a history of recurrent headaches presented for further evaluation. On further workup, hemoglobin and total WBC count were normal while an elevated platelet count was seen. Bone marrow aspiration showed increased megakaryocytes and a JAK2 mutation. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is essential thrombocytosis (a.k.a essential thrombocythemia).

Essential thrombocytosis is a clonal stem cell disorder characterized by elevated platelet count with no evidence of prolonged platelet survival.

It is estimated that a significant number of patients with essential thrombocytosis are diagnosed incidentally when the patient obtains a complete blood count for an unrelated reason.

Symptoms such as headaches, dizziness, and, visual changes can be seen in the minority of symptomatic patients. Complications such as thrombosis, bleeding (likely due to qualitative and quantitative alterations in the platelets), and first-trimester pregnancy loss are seen in patients with significant thrombocytosis.

Thrombocytosis also leads to certain microvascular manifestations such as :

  • Headaches
  • Lightheadedness or syncope
  • Atypical chest pain
  • Acral paresthesia
  • Livedo reticularis
  • Erythromelalgia (transient burning sensation of hands and feet)
  • Transient visual disturbances such as amaurosis fugax, scintillating scotomata, etc 

Bone marrow biopsy reveals prominent large to giant megakaryocytes with abundant cytoplasm and lobulated nucleoli. A vast majority of patients demonstrate JAK2, CALR, or the MPL mutation.

Other options:

Option A: Patients with polycythemia vera present with elevated hemoglobin levels.

Option C: Although primary myelofibrosis is associated with JAK 2 mutation, bone marrow aspiration yields a dry tap due to fibrosed bone marrow.

Option D: Chronic myeloid leukemia is characterized by the presence of a Philadelphia chromosome resulting from reciprocal translocation t(9;22) forming the BCR-ABL fusion gene. They have hypercellular marrow due to a massively increased number of maturing granulocytic precursors

questions.text: Identify the pathology in the given radiograph of a newborn.
questions.solution:
The given radiograph of a newborn shows imperforate anus/anal atresia. 

Anorectal atresia, also known as imperforate anus, refers to a spectrum of abnormalities of the rectum and anus. Incidence is one in every 5,000 live birth.

This disease is commonly associated with a group of congenital anomalies. These anomalies are called VACTRL and they are comprised of:

  • Vertebral defects
  • Anal defects
  • Cardiac defects
  • Tracheoesophageal fistula
  • Renal defects
  • Limb defects 

Children affected with this condition present with failure to pass meconium and abdominal distension.

The above radiograph is a lateral film taken with the child in a prone position. This is used to assess the level of atresia. If the distance between the distal air bubble and the lead probe is greater than 1 cm it indicates a high defect. Conversely, if the distance between these two points is less than 1 cm it indicates a low defect.

questions.text: A 45-year-old alcoholic with a history of binge drinking presents with an episode of vomiting bright red blood. His vitals are stable. What is the most probable diagnosis here?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for the above-mentioned clinical presentation is Mallory Weiss tear as the patient's vitals are stable.

Mallory Weiss Syndrome:

  • It is a common cause of upper gastrointestinal bleeding due to the presence of longitudinal superficial mucosal lacerations (Mallory-Weiss tears).
  • They occur primarily in the lower esophagus close to the gastroesophageal junction.
  • It mainly occurs in patients with repetitive forceful retching and vomiting and is associated with heavy alcohol intake.
  • The concurrent presence of portal hypertension with esophageal varices and hiatal hernia in patients with Mallory Weiss syndrome is not uncommon.

Boerhaave syndrome:

  • It is a transmural perforation of the esophagus (while the Mallory Weiss tear is a mucosal tear).
  • Clinical presentation:
    • Mackler's Triad:
      • Vomiting
      • lower thoracic pain
      • subcutaneous emphysema
    • Other classical findings include deranged vitals tachypnea, tachycardia, fever, and hypotension.
    • Diaphoresis and abdominal rigidity can also be present

questions.text: A patient was brought to the hospital following a road traffic accident. The patient was disoriented. CT head showed no evidence of hemorrhage, but features of cerebral edema and raised intracranial pressure were seen. Which of the following drugs can be used for the initial management of raised intracranial pressure?
questions.solution:
Mannitol can be given as first-line management to decrease the edema associated with the injury.

If there is an associated bleed then craniotomy and evacuation might be needed as well which depends on the clinical picture.  

Initial management of raised intracranial pressure (ICP):

  • Airway protection 
  • Positioning the head up 20–30° (reverse Trendelenburg positioning)
  • A bolus of mannitol up to 1 g/kg for free water diuresis (the effect is delayed by 20 min)
  • Hypertonic saline (3% or 5%)
  • Maintaining fluid and electrolyte balance
  • Seizure control
  • Sedation using a combination of opiates and barbiturates
  • Ventriculostomy and/or craniectomy may be needed for definitive decompression.

ICP normally varies between 4 and 14 mmHg. Sustained ICP levels above 20 mmHg can injure the brain. The goal of therapy in raised ICP is to maintain the ICP <20 mmHg.

Note: Cerebellar tonsillar herniation through the foramen magnum compresses medullary vasomotor and respiratory centers, classically producing Cushing’s triad. It is comprised of:

  • Bradycardia
  • Raised blood pressure
  • Irregular respirations.

questions.text: All of the following are features of tetralogy of Fallot except:
questions.solution:
An atrial septal defect is not seen in a patient with tetralogy of Fallot.

 The primary defect gives rise to the 4 anatomical components of TOF which are:

  • Ventricular septal defect (VSD) 
  • Obstruction to right ventricular outflow - Pulmonic stenosis (PS)
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)
  • Overriding (or dextroposition) of the aorta

Tetrology of Fallot(TOF):

  • TOF is the most common cyanotic congenital heart disease
  • The primary defect is an anterior deviation of the infundibular septum (the muscular septum that separates the aortic and pulmonary outflows).
  • Obstruction to pulmonary arterial blood flow is usually at both the right ventricular infundibulum (subpulmonic area) and the pulmonary valve.
  • The degree of pulmonary outflow obstruction determines the degree of the patient’s cyanosis and the age of first presentation.

questions.text: Following appearance on IVP is  seen in______
questions.solution:
The characteristic sign in the given IVP depicts cobra head/ adder head deformity seen in bilateral ureterocele.

Ureterocoele is a cystic enlargement of the intramural ureter and affects females more often than males. They are mostly detected on routine prenatal screening, or as an incidental finding on imaging studies in adults.

If they present clinically, they usually present with an infection in children, whereas in adults, they can present with stones in the lower ureter. Ureterocoeles can enlarge and obstruct the bladder neck or the contralateral ureteric orifice.

The classic sign of a ureterocele on intravenous urography is a ‘cobra head’ or ‘adder head’ sign or 'spring onion sign'. It refers to a dilated, contrast-filled distal ureter, surrounded by a thin rim of the ureteric wall and bladder mucosa. On ultrasonography, it can be seen as a fluid-filled cystic mass in the bladder.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents for an antenatal check-up and is currently on lithium for her bipolar disorder. This drug must be stopped, due to the risk of development of which of the following conditions in the fetus?
questions.solution:
Lithium should be stopped as it can cause an Ebstein anomaly in the newborn.

Ebstein anomaly is characterized by the downward displacement of the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle, which results in a thin-walled, low-pressure, “atrialized” segment of the right ventricle due to the anomalous attachment of the tricuspid leaflets.

Lithium can also cause macrocephaly as a teratogenic effect. 

Lithium use in early pregnancy causes Ebstein anomaly in the fetus. Fetal lithium exposure is associated with neonatal goiter, CNS depression, hypotonia (floppy baby syndrome), and cardiac murmur.

questions.text: A patient presented to the hospital with a history of increased frequency of micturition. On cystoscopy, a pale ureteric orifice was seen. The patient's KUB X-ray is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and KUB X-ray point to the diagnosis of bladder tuberculosis. 

The earliest sign of tuberculosis of the bladder observed by cystoscopy is the pallor of the mucosa around the ureteric orifice due to submucous edema. Subsequently, tubercles may be seen.

A thimble bladder is a small contracted bladder due to fibrosis of the bladder walls. It is seen in bladder tuberculosis and is appreciated in a micturating cystourethrogram (MCU). The X-ray KUB given above shows a thimble bladder.

questions.text: A newborn at birth was noticed to have a herniated liver and small intestine via the umbilicus. The herniated mass was covered with membranes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Failure of the intestinal loops to return to the abdominal cavity results in omphalocele or exomphalos which os covered with a membrane.

Omphalocele is a congenital malformation in which the abdominal viscera protrudes through a wide umbilical defect. The defect arises due to failure of the intestinal loops in the physiological umbilical hernia to return to the body cavity during the 6th to 10th weeks. The bowel loops are covered by amnion. 

A small omphalocele contains only the intestines. A large omphalocele may contain other viscera such as stomach, liver, spleen, and large intestine, along with the small intestine. Omphalocele is commonly associated with other congenital anomalies (e.g., trisomy 13, trisomy 18, or Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome) and causes increased levels of α-fetoprotein. 

Other options:

Option B: Gastroschisis is the major disorder to consider in the differential diagnosis of an omphalocele. It can be differentiated from omphalocele by its absence of a membranous sac and paraumbilical location (commonly to the right of the umbilicus).

Option C: In a persistent vitellointestinal duct, the vitelline duct remains patent over its entire length. This results in the formation of direct communication between the umbilicus and the intestinal tract. A fecal discharge may then be found at the umbilicus.

Option D: Bochdalek hernia (posterior) is the most common type of diaphragmatic hernia. Herniation occurs through the pleuroperitoneal foramen.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with chest pain and breathlessness which increases on lying down and is relieved on sitting upright. On examination, heart sounds are muffled. His chest X-ray is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and X-ray appearance of the money bag heart is suggestive of pericardial effusion.

Plain PA chest X-ray shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette. There is effacement of the normal cardiac borders, development of a ‘flask’ or ‘water bottle’ cardiac configuration, and bilateral hilar overlay which are features of pericardial effusion. It is also known as money bag or leather bottle-shaped heart.

Pericardial effusions occur when excess fluid collects in the pericardial space (a normal pericardial sac contains approximately 30-50 mL of fluid).

Investigation of choice: Echocardiography.

Signs on plain radiograph include:

  • Globular enlargement of the cardiac shadow giving a water bottle configuration.
  • Lateral CXR may show a vertical opaque line (pericardial fluid) separating a vertical lucent line directly behind the sternum (paracardial fat) anteriorly from a similar lucent vertical lucent line (epicardial fat) posteriorly; this is known as the Oreo cookie sign.

questions.text: While examining a patient with a right forearm fracture, you ask him to make a fist. The following finding is noted during this procedure. What is the sign called as ?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the pointing index sign and is associated with median nerve injury at the forearm or elbow.

The pointing index sign is seen in supracondylar fractures of the humerus.

This finding occurs as a result of injury to the anterior interosseous nerve, a branch of the median nerve. It results in the loss of function of both flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) and flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS). Hence, the index finger sticks out when the patient is asked to clasp their hand. 

Other options:

Option A:  In Froment's sign, due to the weakness of the adductor pollicis muscle, the adduction of the thumb is lost. When asked to hold an object, the patient tries to hold the object by using the flexor pollicis longus muscle. This produces flexion at the interphalangeal joint while holding the book.

Option C:  Paralysis of flexor pollicis brevis can occur in median nerve injury at the arm and elbow. Benediction hand sign (attempt to make a fist gives pointed index and middle finger) and Ochsner's clasping test (attempt to clasp both hands show pointing index finger) are used to test such injuries.

Option D:  Policeman tip deformity, also known as waiter's tip hand or porter's tip hand, is a finding of Erb's palsy due to injury of the upper trunk of the brachial plexus involving C5 and C6. The hand is adducted, medially rotated, and hangs by the side with the elbow extended and pronated.

questions.text: A patient was admitted to the ICU 48 hours after the fracture of the femur. The saturation of oxygen in the rebreathing unit was 100% but his SpO2 remained at 60%. The patient is in a state of confusion. Chest radiograph showed lung fields to be clear. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of the above clinical scenario is a fat embolism. The presence of respiratory insufficiency and altered mental status following a long bone fracture (fracture of the femur) favors the diagnosis.

Fat embolism syndrome results from the presence of numerous fat emboli within the microcirculation. It most commonly occurs after the fracture of the long bone or pelvis. They present with non-specific symptoms like tachypnea, tachycardia, and fever that manifest within 24- 48 hours after the injury. Damage to the microvasculature of various organs leads to :

  • Mild hypoxia to rapidly progressing respiratory failure.
  • Depression of the central nervous system.
  • Petechial rashes
  • Hemorrhagic lesions of the retina.

Related Pearl: Gurd's criteria for diagnosing fat embolism syndrome

Major criteria
  • Axillary or subconjunctival petechiae
  • Hypoxemia with PaO2 <60 mmHg, FIO2 < 0.4
  • CNS depression disproportionate to the hypoxemia
  • Pulmonary edema

Minor criteria

  • Tachycardia (HR >110 beats per minute)
  • Pyrexia (temp >38.50C)
  • Emboli visible in retina
  • Fat globules in urine
  • Fat globules in sputum
  • Unexplanied drop in hematocrit or platelet count 
  • Increased ESR

 At least one major criterion and four minor criteria are required to make a diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome.

questions.text:
A patient with no comorbidities presents with electrolyte values as shown below. The patient had a normal ECG. What is the preferred treatment for this patient among the options given below?

Serum K+: 3.0mmol/L
questions.solution:
The patient is experiencing mild hypokalaemia (normal levels are from 3.5 mmol/L- 5.mmol/L)and hence, PotChlor(Potassium Chloride) is given as treatment. 

Treatment of hypokalaemia:

Hypokalaemia is treated based on factors such as serum K+ levels, their rate of decline, and other clinical factors such as cardiac disease, digoxin therapy, renal deficit, medications (nonsparing K+ diuretics), etc. They should be considered while correcting hypokalaemia to reduce overcorrection leading to hyperkalemia.

Treatment is based on the cause, as re-distributive hypokalaemia, if corrected urgently can lead to rebound hyperkalemia when the underlying cause is resolved.

Oral replacement with PotChlor (potassium chloride) is the treatment of choice. In case of associated hypophosphatemia, potassium phosphate oral or IV can be given, whereas, in metabolic acidosis, potassium bicarbonate or citrate can also be considered.

Use of intravenous KCl is limited to patients who cannot take it orally, in severe hypokalemia (<2.5 mmol/L, patients with complications or at risk of arrhythmias, etc.) However, cardiac monitoring is needed in an intensive care setting when the IV route is preferred. It should be administered in saline solutions and not dextrose as the latter can increase insulin secretion and exacerbate hypokalaemia by the intracellular shift of K+.

The intravenous route when used should be given via femoral veins preferably as it decreases the risk of local concentration and cardiac arrhythmias which can occur when given via the internal jugular or subclavian central lines.

Note:

In cases of excessive sympathetic activity conditions such as acute head injury, or theophylline overdose, high-dose propranolol can be considered which can correct hypokalaemia without rebound hyperkalemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common side effect of cholecystectomy?
questions.solution:
The most common side effect of cholecystectomy is steatorrhea. Steatorrhea is fecal fat excretion of more than 7 g/24 hours or >6% /24 hours, when on a diet of 100 to 150 g of fat. Gall Bladder is the major source of Bile and Bile plays an important role in the absorption of fats/lipids. Hence Cholecystectomy can lead to steatorrhea.

Digestion of Lipids

  • Pancreatic lipase is the most important enzymes involved in lipid digestion. Main products of its action are FFA and 2-monoglycerides (2-monoacylglycerols
  • Colipase is an accessory factor secreted in the pancreatic juice that helps to stabilize pancreatic lipase in an active conformation
  • Bile acids emulsify the insoluble lipids and make them reach the surface of the mucosal cells. Bile acids also activate another pancreatic lipase called cholesterol esterase. 
  • Cholesterol esterase hydrolysis cholesterol esters, esters of fat-soluble vitamins, phospholipids, and triglycerides

questions.text: A young patient presented to the emergency department with pain and swelling of the right knee. Plain radiograph shows the following finding. What is the best treatment for the given condition?

choices.text: Tension band wiring with cancellous screws

questions.solution:
The radiograph shows a displaced patellar fracture. The best treatment for the given condition is tension band wiring with K- wires.

Other treatment options which are available for patellar fracture are:

  • Undisplaced patellar fractures with minimal joint incongruity and intact extensor retinaculum can be treated by cylinder cast.
  • Displaced patellar fractures are usually treated by tension band wiring.
  • Severely comminuted fractures where the reduction of the fragments is difficult are treated by patellectomy.

Related Pearl: Tension band wiring

A tension band wire is a form of internal fixation used to convert distraction forces into compression forces, promoting bone healing.

It is used in:

  • Fracture patella
  • Fracture olecranon 
  • Fracture lateral malleolus
  • Fracture greater trochanter

questions.text: A young male patient was brought to the emergency department in an unconscious state after having suddenly collapsed at a railway station. As there was no pulse felt, cardiopulmonary resuscitation was started and the monitor showed ventricular fibrillation. Immediate defibrillation was performed. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Chest compressions should be resumed immediately following shock delivery.

Pulse check and reanalysis of the cardiac rhythm is performed only after 2 minutes of chest compression and rescue breaths.

This is because the heart is temporarily stunned by a defibrillator shock and so chest compressions would benefit by providing coronary blood flow during this period.

Related Pearl: Adult Basic Life Support (BLS) Algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most radiosensitive tumour?
questions.solution:
The radiosensitive tumor among the following is Ewing's sarcoma. All others are radioresistant tumors.

Ewing sarcoma is a malignant bone tumor characterized by primitive round cells without obvious differentiation. It accounts for 6% to 10% of primary malignant bone tumors.

Ewing sarcoma follows osteosarcoma as the second most common group of bone sarcomas in children. Approximately 80% of affected patients are younger than 20 years. Boys are affected slightly more frequently than girls. Usually, the tumor arises in the diaphysis of long tubular bones, especially the femur and the flat bones of the pelvis. Fever, elevated sedimentation rate, anemia, and leukocytosis may be seen.

Plain radiographs show a destructive lytic tumor with permeative margins that extend into the surrounding soft tissues. The characteristic periosteal reaction produces layers of reactive bone deposited in an onion-skin fashion.

Ewing's sarcoma is managed with a combination of radiotherapy, chemotherapy, and surgery. This sarcoma is highly sensitive to radiotherapy and in certain cases, tumors affecting important bones can be treated with radiotherapy or a combination of radiotherapy and chemotherapy.

Related Pearl: Radiosensitive and Radioresistant Tumors

Highly radiosensitive tumors are

  • Lymphoma
  • Seminoma
  • Myeloma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Wilm’s tumour

 Highly radioresistant tumors are

  • Melanoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma
  • Hepatic carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma

questions.text: A patient comes with a blood pressure of 160/100 mmHg and left-sided facial paralysis and weakness since 8 hours. Her CT appears normal. What would be your next step?
questions.solution:
Sudden onset hemiparesis with an apparently normal CT indicates ischemic stroke in this patient.

Intravenous thrombolysis (alteplase: 0.9 mg/kg ) should be immediately administered to patients with ischemic stroke who arrive in the window period (within 3/4.5 hours of symptom onset) since this patient has arrived 8 hours later which is outside of window period, the appropriate management would be observation and monitoring.

Oral Nefidipine and IV labetalol is not advised immediately because of unpredictable fall in Blood pressure further worsening the ischemia. So, permissible hypertension is allowed in such cases.

*Note: Mechanical thrombectomy is only considered in the case of demonstrable large artery occlusion on CT/MR angiogram.

questions.text: Identify the type of myoma labeled as '4'  in the image given below.
questions.solution:
The type of myoma labeled as '4' is pedunculated submucosal myoma.

Uterine myomas are broadly classified into 3 types.

They are:

  • Intramural: remains within the myometrial wall.
  • Submucous: present inside the uterine cavity and covered only by a thin endometrium.
  • Subserous: present towards the peritoneal surface.

Treatment includes:

  • Hormones to shrink the fibroid
  • Uterine artery embolization.
  • Myomectomy.
  • Total / subtotal hysterectomy.

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy

  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration

  • Red degeneration

  • Sarcomatous change

  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp

  • Inversion of the uterus

  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma

  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia

  • Accompanying adenomyosis

  • Parasitic fibroid

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with a history of facial edema that has now progressed to total body swelling involving the face, abdomen, scrotum, and feet. Urinalysis revealed protein 4+ and a urine protein: creatinine ratio of 3. What is the initial treatment of choice for this child?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and investigations are highly suggestive of minimal change nephrotic syndrome and the initial treatment of choice is corticosteroids such as prednisolone.

Minimal change nephrotic syndrome is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome. It is seen in ages 2-6 years with a clinical picture of nephrotic syndrome, that is, heavy proteinuria, edema, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia. They may be asymptomatic or can present with peripheral edema. Renal biopsy is not required for confirmation and treatment can be initiated if the child fits the standard clinical picture of nephrotic syndrome.

They show excellent response to steroid therapy with prednisone or prednisolone. A daily dose of 2mg/kg (max 60mg) for 6 weeks followed by an alternate dose of 1.5mg/kg (max 40mg) for the next 6-8 weeks is recommended.

Alternative drugs used in steroid-dependent patients, frequent relapsers, steroid-resistant patients, and those with severe corticosteroid toxicity are as follows:

  • Cyclophosphamide
  • Calcineurin inhibitors: Cyclosporine and Tacrolimus
  • Mycophenolate
  • Levamisole
  • Rituximab (chimeric monoclonal antibody against CD20)

Related Pearl: Nephrotic and nephritic syndromes

 

Nephrotic Syndrome

Nephritic Syndrome (Glomerulonephritis)

questions.text: A patient is seen in the OPD after her delivery which was 5 days ago. She presents with smelly greenish vaginal discharge. What is the initial step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is postpartum endometritis however, the next line of management in this patient is to undergo a per vaginal examination to rule out other differentials.

Puerperal infection:

  • The most common site of puerperal infection is a placental site in vaginal delivery and uterine incision in cesarean section.
  • The most common manifestation of puerperal infection is Endometritis.
  • The most common cause of puerperal sepsis is Streptococcus.
  • The most important risk factor for the development of puerperal sepsis is the route of delivery (Cesarean > Vaginal).
  • The only proven way of decreasing uterine infection following cesarean section is by administrating a single dose of ampicillin or 1st generation cephalosporin at the time of cesarean delivery. None of the other steps with respect to surgical closure of the abdomen have proven beneficial in decreasing puerperal infection.
  • Treatment is with antibiotics and symptomatic measures.

questions.text: Which of the following represents type III choledochal cyst from the given image?
questions.solution:
The figure marked C in the given image represents choledochal cyst type III, a cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Choledochal cysts:

Choledochal cysts are congenital cystic dilations of the intrahepatic and/or extrahepatic biliary tree. They present with a triad of jaundice, a palpable upper quadrant mass, and abdominal pain. They are commonly seen in girls. 

Choledochal cyst is classified into five types:

The original classification for choledochal cysts by Alonso–Lej, and colleagues has been modified by Todani and associates to include intrahepatic cystic disease.

  • Type I: is a simple cyst that can involve any portion of the CBD.
  • Type II: It is described as an isolated diverticulum arising from the wall of the CBD
  • Type III: They arise from the intraduodenal portion of the common bile duct and are also known as choledochocele.
  • Type IVA: The cysts consist of multiple dilatations of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Type IVB: These choledochal cysts are multiple dilatations involving only the extrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Type V (Caroli’s disease): It consists of multiple dilatations limited to the intrahepatic bile ducts.

Caroli's disease:

Caroli’s Disease is an autosomal recessive condition of multifocal cystic dilatation of segmental intrahepatic bile ducts. According to Todani's classification, it is classified as a type V choledochal cyst.  

USG may show dilated intrahepatic bile ducts in these individuals. The beaded appearance of intrahepatic bile ducts on the HIDA scan and the central dot sign on CT are characteristic findings associated with Caroli's disease. MRCP is the investigation of choice.

Treatment options:

  • Type I—excision of the cyst with its mucosa and reconstruction by Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy.
  • In type II—excision of the diverticulum and suturing of the CBD wall can be done
  • Type III cysts represent Choledochoceles, consisting of cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum. As type III cysts are associated with the lowest malignancy risk of any choledochal cyst, endoscopic sphincterotomy followed by surveillance is generally recommended over cyst excision with pancreaticoduodenectomy.
  • Type IV, if the cyst is adherent to the portal vein posteriorly, that part of the cyst wall over the portal vein is left behind. But mucosa of the part should be removed. This is named Lily’s operation.
  • Excision of all cystic tissues and reconstruction of the biliary tree is recommended for extrahepatic biliary involvement as in Type 4B and in case of intrahepatic involvement, an additional segmental resection of the liver may be required which can be removed by hepatectomy.
  • Liver transplantation is the preferred treatment of choice in type IV and type V.

Related Pearl: Classification of Choledochal Cysts

Type

Feature

Type I

The most common choledochal cyst type; it involves only the extrahepatic biliary tree and is generally a fusiform dilation.

Type II

Saccular diverticulum off the common bile duct and may be mistaken for an accessory gallbladder.

Type III

A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Type IV

Type IVa: Cysts involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree

Type IVb: Multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree.

Type V

Also known as Caroli disease, involve the intrahepatic ducts only.

An increase in the number of intraepithelial lymphocytes is a sensitive marker of celiac disease, even in the absence of epithelial damage and villous atrophy. MARSH's Score is used to assess celiac disease histologically. 

Dermatitis herpetiformis can occur in as many as 10% of patients.

The mainstay of treatment is a gluten-free diet.

questions.text: A young boy with fatigue is found to have a haemoglobin of <9 g/dl. Peripheral smear showed sickle-shaped RBCs. What is the next best step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image are diagnostic of sickle cell anemia. The next best step is blood transfusion. 

Sickle cell anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to the T-to-A point mutation in the sixth codon of the β-globin gene. This results in the replacement of glutamate residue with valine. This causes the production of sickle-shaped red blood cells due to the polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin (HbS).

The clinical features of sickle cell disease are due to the tendency of HbS molecules to stack into polymers when deoxygenated. The features are:

  • Moderately severe hemolytic anemia with jaundice.
  • Painful bone crisis- hand-foot syndrome or dactylitis of the bones of hands and feet.
  • Acute chest syndrome typically presents with fever, cough, chest pain, and pulmonary infiltrates.
  • Hyposthenuria- inability to concentrate urine.
  • Aplastic crisis stems from the infection of red cell progenitors by parvovirus B19, which causes a transient cessation of erythropoiesis and a sudden worsening of the anemia.
  • Spleen
    • In children- splenic sequestration crises occur which results in splenomegaly due to red pulp congestion.
    • Adolescence or early adulthood- autosplenectomy occurs due to splenic infarction, fibrosis, and progressive shrinkage.
    • Increased susceptibility to infection with encapsulated organisms like pneumococcal, meningococcal, and Haemophilus influenza septicemia, but can be reduced by vaccination and prophylactic antibiotics.
  • Other clinical features- priapism, leg ulcers, stroke, retinopathy, pigment gallstones, and growth retardation.

 The diagnosis is suggested by the clinical findings, the presence of irreversibly sickled RBCs on peripheral smear, and hemoglobin electrophoresis showing increased HbA2, HbF, and S spike.

Disease-modifying drugs such as hydroxyurea can be given to patients with sickle cell anemia since it reduces the incidence of adverse vaso-occlusive vents. Blood transfusions are used to treat and prevent complications of sickle cell disease, including preparation for surgery, symptomatic anemia, acute stroke, multi-organ failure and acute chest syndrome

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presents with the following finding. What is the WHO clinical stage of HIV?
questions.solution:
Oral candidiasis (thrush) is categorized as WHO clinical stage 3.

Oral Candidiasis (Thrush), and oral hairy leukoplakia, are oral lesions characterized in WHO clinical Stage 3. They generally occur in patients with CD4+ T cell counts of <300/μL.

Differentiating oral candidiasis and oral hairy leukoplakia:

  • Oral Candidiasis (Thrush) appears as a white, cheesy exudate, on an erythematous mucosa in the posterior oropharynx. The diagnosis is made by direct examination of pseudohyphal elements.
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia presents as white, frondlike lesions, generally along the lateral borders of the tongue and sometimes on the adjacent buccal mucosa(image below). Despite its name, oral hairy leukoplakia is not considered premalignant. Lesions are associated with the Ebstein-Barr virus (EBV).

questions.text: An 80-year-old man developed right-sided calf muscle pain and swelling. He was bedridden following a right inter-trochanteric fracture. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of deep vein thrombosis. It occurs due to immobilization and venous stasis.

It most commonly occurs in the calf veins and less often in the proximal veins of the thigh and pelvis. It is caused due to Virchow's triad:

  • Hemodynamic changes (stasis or turbulence)
  • Hypercoagulabilty 
  • Endothelial injury/dysfunction

It is usually asymptomatic. Some patients may present with pain in the calf or thigh. There may be an increase in temperature and pulse rate. Calf swelling and tenderness may be noted. Increased pain on passive dorsiflexion of the foot (Homan's test), although frequently used is now regarded as an unreliable sign.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient presents with cold intolerance, dry skin, constipation, and on examination slow ankle jerk with a TSH level of 15 IU/L and low T3, and T4. Of the following, the next best step in the management of this patient is to:

choices.text: Order a thyroid radionuclide uptake and scan

questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is hypothyroidism. Thyroid hormone replacement with levothyroxine should be started immediately after diagnosis.

Laboratory investigations in a patient with hypothyroidism would show low levels of total and free T3, T4, and rT3, with high TSH levels and normal combined protein levels.

Normally, the thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) is released by the hypothalamus. It stimulates the pituitary gland to release the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), which in turn stimulates the thyroid gland to produce T3 and T4 hormones. Elevated TSH with a low level of free T4 is suggestive of primary hypothyroidism.

In the case of secondary hypothyroidism, TSH levels may be low, normal, or even slightly increased. The latter is due to the secretion of immunoactive but bio-inactive forms of TSH. The diagnosis is confirmed by the detection of a low unbound T4 level. 

Patients with hypothyroidism often present with tiredness, weakness, dry skin, hair loss, difficulty concentrating, poor memory, constipation, cold intolerance, and weight gain with poor appetite. On examination, they may have cool peripheral extremities, puffy faces, hyporeflexia, bradycardia, and peripheral edema.

The best outcomes occur when levothyroxine therapy is started immediately after diagnosis. The clinical effects of levothyroxine replacement are slow to appear. 

If there is no residual function, the daily replacement dose of levothyroxine is usually 1.6 μg/kg body weight (typically 100–150 μg), ideally taken at least 30 minutes before breakfast.

TSH responses are gradual and should be determined 2 months following the initiation of treatment or change in dose. Once the full replacement is achieved and TSH levels are stable, TSH measurement is recommended at annual intervals.

In patients who have developed hypothyroidism following treatment of Graves' disease, lower doses are needed for replacement. This is because there is often underlying autonomous function, necessitating lower replacement doses (typically 75–125 μg/d).

questions.text: A young male patient sustained a right tibial shaft fracture following a road traffic accident. The patient's right leg was immobilized with a plaster cast. The patient later presents to the emergency department with severe pain in the leg. On examination, distal pulses are absent, there is an increase in pain on passive stretch, and on opening the plaster the right leg appears edematous and numerous blisters are seen. Considering the suspected diagnosis, what would be the most appropriate management in this case?

choices.text: Opening of the plaster is sufficient

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests acute compartment syndrome, and it is treated immediately with fasciotomy.

Compartment syndrome is a condition characterized by elevated pressure within the osteofascial compartment resulting in impaired local circulation.

The classic features of ischemia in acute compartment syndrome include the 5 Ps:

  • Pain: Pain is the first symptom of acute compartment syndrome. Ischemic muscle is highly sensitive to touch. On the passive stretching of the muscles, severe pain can be elicited. 
  • Paresthesia: Paresthesia and hypoesthesia may be noted due to compression of nerves traversing the affected compartment. They are the first signs of nerve ischemia.
  • Pallor: Pallor of the skin may not always be seen. The skin outside the compartment may be normally perfused, as only the intra-compartmental perfusion may be affected.
  • Paralysis: Paralysis of muscle groups affected in that compartment is a late sign.
  • Pulselessness: Usually, the peripheral pulses and capillary return are intact in the early stages, unless there is a major arterial injury. If pulses are absent, arteriography is indicated. 

The diagnosis can be confirmed by measuring the intra-compartmental pressure using a split catheter introduced into the compartment. The difference between diastolic and compartment pressure is known as the differential pressure (ΔP). A differential pressure (ΔP) of less than 30 mm Hg (4.00 kilopascals) is an indication for immediate compartment decompression.

Treatment: The threatened compartment must be promptly decompressed, merely splitting the plaster is utterly useless and the limb must be nursed flat. Elevating the limb causes a further decrease in end capillary pressure and aggravates muscle ischemia. In the case of compartment syndrome in the leg, Fasciotomy means opening all four compartments (anterior, lateral, deep posterior and superficial compartments). Wounds to be left open and inspected 2 days later, if tissues are healthy, the wounds can be sutured. If there is muscle necrosis, debridement is to be carried out.

questions.text: A 56-year-old multiparous woman presented with grade II/III uterine prolapse with cystocele. She complains of passing urine on coughing and sneezing. What is the type of urinary incontinence seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The type of urinary incontinence present in a patient with prolapse and cystocele experiencing urination on coughing and sneezing is stress incontinence.

Stress incontinence refers to the involuntary leakage of urine when there is increased intraabdominal pressure (eg, coughing, sneezing, laughing, Valsalva maneuver). There is an absence of detrusor muscle contraction, seen in urodynamic studies.

Causes:

  • Age and menopause - due to estrogen deficiency
  • Multiparity - due to loss of pelvic muscle tone
  • Obesity
  • Constipation, chronic cough
  • Pelvic organ prolapse
  • Pregnancy - due to the effect of progesterone and pressure of the gravid uterus on the bladder neck.
  • Puerperium - due to descent of the bladder neck, loss of urethro-vesical angle, and reduced pelvic muscle tone 
  • Surgical repair of vesicovaginal fistula

Grading of genuine stress incontinence (GSI) :

  • Grade I: Incontinence with only severe stress, such as coughing, sneezing, and jogging.
  • Grade II: Incontinence with moderate stress, such as fast walking, and going up and down the stairs.
  • Grade III: Incontinence with mild stress such as standing.

Investigations are only done prior to surgery to confirm the diagnosis. They include the stress test, cotton swab or Q tip test, Marshall and Bonney’s test, urethroscopy, and urodynamic studies. These are not required prior to conservative management.

Conservative management includes Kegel's pelvic exercises, electric nerve stimulation, devices like pessaries, vaginal cones, and artificial sphincters. Medical treatment with estrogen creams, anti-adrenergic, venlafaxine, and imipramine may be useful.

Other options:

Option A: Overflow incontinence is an old term that refers to the inability to empty the bladder, with involuntary, continuous urinary dribbling. Currently, it refers to another presentation of urge incontinence. 

Option B: Urge incontinence is the involuntary escape of urine when there is an imminent need to urinate. It occurs due to detrusor muscle overactivity or detrusor instability. It is seen more commonly in old women with decreased bladder capacity, decreased sensation, and central nervous system (CNS) inhibition. 

Option D: Neurogenic bladder occurs in patients with neurogenic dysfunction leading to detrusor hyperreflexia. Conditions such as multiple sclerosis, stroke, Parkinson's disease, and spinal injury give rise to this. They present with urgency or urge incontinence.

questions.text: The following diagram charts the population change over years from 1983 to 1989 in a given place. What is the statistical diagram used here?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a component bar graph or a component bar chart. The bars can be divided into two or more parts where each part represents a certain item, proportional to the magnitude of that particular item (males and females in this image).

It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data.

The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups. Frequency polygon and Ogive can be constructed using a histogram, not a component bar chart

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida at 18 weeks of gestation presents for her antenatal check-up. Her random plasma glucose level was 243 mg/dL and thus she was asked to undergo further tests. The fasting blood glucose levels were 146mg/dL and HbA1c was 7.6%.  Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A fasting blood sugar > 126 mg/dL , random blood sugar > 200mg/dL and HbA1c> 6.5% is suggestive of overt diabetes or pregestational diabetes. 

The following are the lab results that would be suggestive of overt diabetes in a mother.

  • Fasting blood sugar at least 126 mg/dL
  • A random blood sugar of at least 200 mg/dL
  • HbA1c of at least 6.5%

Cardiac anomalies are most commonly seen in the fetuses of overt-diabetic mothers. Musculoskeletal, urogenital, and CNS anomalies are also seen,

Congenital malformations occur at a higher rate, in overt diabetes than in gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). This is because GDM manifests in the second trimester and by then organogenesis would be complete.

Threshold values for gestational diabetes (75 g OGTT):

Plasma glucose Glucose concentration threshold
Fasting 92 mg/dl
1 hr OGTT 180 mg/dl
2 hr OGTT 153 mg/dl

 

According to WHO and ADA guidelines, the one-step approach omits the screening test and simplifies diagnostic testing for gestational diabetes mellitus by performing only a 75-gram, two-hour oral GTT.

Diagnostic criteria or cut-off values with a 75 g OGTT are as follows:

  • Fasting: 92 mg/dl 
  • 1 hour: 180 mg/dl  
  • 2 hours: 153 mg/dl

Two-step approach :

  • The first step (screening) is a 50-gram one-hour glucose challenge test (GCT) at 24-28 weeks of gestation who are not previously diagnosed with diabetes.
  • If the plasma glucose level measured 1 h after the load is ≥130, a 100-gram, three-hour oral glucose tolerance test (GTT) is done, which is the diagnostic test for gestational diabetes mellitus.

 At least 2 of the following 4 values should be raised for a diagnosis to be made:

  • Fasting: 95 mg/dL (5.3 mmol/L)
  • 1 h: 180 mg/dL (10.0 mmol/L)
  • 2 h: 155 mg/dL (8.6 mmol/L)
  • 3 h: 140 mg/dL (7.8 mmol/L)

Other options:

Option A: MODY or maturity-onset diabetes of the young is a monogenic form of diabetes that occurs < 25 years. There is impaired insulin secretion, but no antibodies.

Option D: LADA  is a form of diabetes mellitus affecting lean and thin adults less than 50 years with a positive family history. It is insulin-dependent and associated with autoantibodies.

questions.text: A 55 year old patient presented with chronic projectile vomiting and weight loss. What is the expected metabolic abnormality to be seen here ?

choices.text: Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia
Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hypernatremia
Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hypercalcemia
Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic acidosis with hyponatremia

questions.solution:
The expected metabolic abnormality to be seen in this patient is hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia.

The persistent vomiting results in these abnormalities along with paradoxical aciduria. 

  • Persistent vomiting results in loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the development of metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-).
  • Kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3- causing hyponatremia. However, loss of sodium stimulates the secretion of aldosterone through the RAAS pathway.
  • The aldosterone causes active reabsorption of sodium in exchange for K+ and H+ ions.
  • Loss of potassium ions leads to the development of hypokalemia.
  • Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in aciduria. It is called paradoxical aciduria, since the body initially lost H+ ions due to the loss of HCl, and instead of compensating for that loss, the body loses more H+ ions through urine.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presented with itching and malodorous discharge in the vagina which started a week earlier. On examination, the vaginal walls are congested with foul-smelling vaginal discharge. Whiff's test is positive and the gram stain shows the presence of clue cells. This infection is commonly treated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Vaginal itching, foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge, and a positive Whiff test with clue cells in the gram staining suggest bacterial vaginosis. It is treated with metronidazole.

Bacterial vaginosis:

It is caused due to the alteration in the normal vaginal flora. There is a decrease in the number of lactobacilli. These lactobacilli reduce the pH and release hydrogen peroxide which is antibacterial. Therefore, a decrease in the number of lactobacilli leads to an increase in the number of other organisms like Hemophilus vaginalis, Gardnerella, Mobiluncus, and Mycoplasma hominis. 

According to Amsel's criteria, the discharge has the following characteristics. 

  • White milky non-viscous discharge, adherent to the vaginal wall
  • The pH of the discharge is more than 4.5
  • Fishy odor when mixed with 10% KOH. This is called the Whiff test.
  • Presence of clue cells-the epithelial cells has a fuzzy border due to the adherence of bacteria.
  • Decrease in the number of lactobacilli and increase in the number of Gardnerella and other bacteria.

It is treated with 500 mg of metronidazole twice daily for 7 days.

The below image shows the presence of clue cells.

Options C and D: Tetracycline and azithromycin are used in the treatment of chlamydial infection. They usually present with vaginal discharge, dysuria, increased urinary frequency, and sometimes cervicitis.

questions.text: Serum beta hCG testing is required to diagnose which of the following conditions?

choices.text: Pregnancy associated with Neural tube defects

questions.solution:

The Ehlers–Danlos syndromes (EDS) are a heterogeneous group of heritable connective tissue disorders (HCTDs) characterized by joint hypermobility, skin hyperextensibility, and tissue fragility.
