questions.text: A 35-year-old man who had witnessed a terrorist attack has been experiencing frequent intrusive flashbacks and nightmares about the incident. He avoids the places that remind him of it.  He is significantly distressed, has difficulty falling asleep, and frequently feels anxious for the last 6 months. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with re-experiences (flashbacks and nightmares), avoidance of the stimuli associated with the attacks, and hyperarousal (impaired sleep and anxiety) for more than one month are suggestive of post-traumatic stress disorder(PTSD).

PTSD is a psychiatric disorder characterized by increased stress and anxiety occurring after a stressful or traumatic event, (e.g., witnessing or being involved in violent accidents, crime, war, assault, kidnapping, natural disaster, life-threatening illness, physical or sexual abuse). 

The predisposing factors for this condition include:

  • Presence of childhood trauma
  • Borderline, paranoid, dependent, or antisocial personality disorder traits
  • Inadequate family or peer support system
  • Female gender
  • Genetic susceptibility to psychiatric illness
  • Recent stressful life changes
  • Recent excessive intake of alcohol

Symptoms of PTSD can be divided into four types:

  • Intrusion symptoms
    • Flashbacks- The individual may act and feel as if the traumatic event is reoccurring 
    • Nightmares of the event
  • Hyperarousal 
    • Increased startle response
    • Insomnia
    • Hypervigilance
    • Difficulty concentrating
    • Reckless and self-destructive behavior
    • Irritability and anxiety
  • Avoidance symptoms:  
    • avoiding memories, thoughts, and feelings of the event
    • avoiding external reminders of the traumatic event
  • Negative cognitions and mood associated with the traumatic event
    • Inability to remember an important aspect of the traumatic event
    • Feelings of depersonalization and derealization
    • Anhedonia
    • Negative emotional state- fear, horror, anger, guilt, or shame

The duration of these symptoms should be > 1 month to label it as PTSD.

Psychotherapies found to be effective for PTSD include exposure therapy, trauma-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy, eye movement desensitization, and abreaction. SSRIs may be prescribed as first-line treatment.

Other options:

Option A: Adjustment disorder is an emotional response to stressful situations like financial issues, medical illnesses, or relation­ship problems that develop within 3 months of the stressor. The stressor in adjustment disorder can be of any severity. In adjustment disorder, the individual does not experience intrusive symptoms like flashbacks and nightmares, hyperarousal symptoms, and avoidance symptoms.

Option B: Acute stress disorder presents with the same symptoms as PTSD, but the symptoms usually occur immediately after the trauma and persist for a period of 3 days to up to 1 month after the trauma.

Option C: Persistent complex bereavement disorder occurs after the death of a loved one. Since the death, for 12 months or more, the individual may experience persistent yearning/longing for the deceased, intense sorrow, and emotional pain, preoccupation with the deceased, and the circumstances of the death.

questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred initial treatment for an empyema that is uni-loculated?
questions.solution:
The preferred initial treatment in the case of uni-loculated empyema is chest tube drainage with antibiotics. 

Empyema is a collection of pus in the pleural space that can be uni-loculated or complex (with internal septations). It can occur due to a parapneumonic effusion or due to direct inoculation from trauma.

Treatment of empyema includes antibiotics and drainage of the infected pleural fluid. Empiric antibiotics are started initially and later changed based on the type of effusion and local guidelines.

The choice of drainage technique is patient-based and varies on several factors including the state of the patient. However, a general concept is as below.

  • In small uncomplicated parapneumonic effusions, drainage is not necessary unless it causes severe respiratory dysfunction.
  • In complicated parapneumonic effusions that are free-flowing or uni-loculated, a  chest tube or catheter drainage is the procedure of choice.
  • Complicated effusions with loculations need additional drains along with a reassessment of the tube position and antibiotic coverage.

A CT scan is used to assess the response to treatment and fluid collection.

If drainage is not adequate with chest tubes, then additional techniques like intrapleural tissue plasminogen activator/deoxyribonuclease (tPA/DNase) or Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery (VATS) can be tried.

The rationale of using tissue plasminogen activator/deoxyribonuclease is that it reduces the internal septations and helps in drainage leading to faster resolution of empyema. 

VATS is used to visualize the pleural cavity directly and resolve the empyema.

Note:

Open thoracotomy and decortication are only done in refractory and chronic cases.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most dependent part of a female?
questions.solution:
The rectouterine pouch, which is also called the pouch of Douglas is the most dependent part of a female.

Peritoneum of the female pelvis:

In females, the peritoneum covers the anterior and anterolateral surfaces of the rectum, uterus, and urinary bladder. Spaces found in the female pelvis are:

Pararectal fossae: Present on either side of the rectum. They are limited laterally by the peritoneum that covers the uterosacral ligaments. 

Paravesical fossae: Present on either side of the bladder. It is limited laterally by the peritoneum which covers the round ligament of the uterus.

Rectouterine pouch (pouch of Douglas): The peritoneum which covers the anterior surface of the rectum is reflected anteriorly to cover the posterior surface of the posterior fornix of the vagina and the uterus, forming a rectouterine pouch.

Vesicouterine pouch: The peritoneum covering the fundus and body of the uterus, is reflected anteriorly to cover the posterosuperior surface of the bladder forming a vesicouterine pouch.

Ovarian fossa: It is a shallow depression in the peritoneal lining of the lateral pelvic wall between the peritoneal ridges. It is formed by the obliterated umbilical arteries anteriorly, the ureter posteriorly, and the external iliac vessels above. It lies behind the lateral attachment of the broad ligament and contains the ovary in nulliparous females.

This patient's clinical features with h/o honey-crusted lesions on the face (impetigo) are suggestive of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). Patients will present with haematuria and urine microscopy will reveal red blood cells.

The PSGN patient presents with hematuria, red cell casts in the urine, azotemia, oliguria, hypertension, mild to moderate proteinuria, and edema (features of the nephritic syndrome). It usually appears 1 to 4 weeks after a streptococcal infection of the pharynx or skin (impetigo). It occurs most frequently in children 6 to 10 years of age. In adults, it is less benign. Poststreptococcal GN is caused by immune complexes containing streptococcal antigens and specific antibodies, which are formed in situ.

The histologic picture shows enlarged hypercellular glomeruli. The hypercellularity is caused by infiltration by leukocytes and the proliferation of endothelial and mesangial cells. The proliferation and leukocyte infiltration are typically global and diffuse.

questions.text: For a population of 10,000, what does a sex ratio of more than 1000 mean?
questions.solution:
For a population of 10000, if the sex ratio is more than 1000, it means males are less than 5000 i.e., less than half the population.

The sex ratio refers to the number of females per 1000 males. An ideal sex ratio would be 1000 which indicates the population comprises an equal number of males and females.

Sex ratio >1000 indicates that there are more females than males in a population. Sex ratio <1000 indicates that there are fewer females compared to males in the population.

  • According to NFHS-5 (2019-21), the sex ratio in India was 1020 females per 1000 males.

  • Kerala was the only state to hold a favourable sex ratio in the last census. It currently holds a sex ratio of 1121 females per 1000 males. (NFHS-5 data)
  • Puducherry was the only union territory that had a favourable sex ratio in the last census. It currently has a sex ratio of 1112 females per 1000 males. (NFHS-5 data)

questions.text: Which of the following is contraindicated in patients with acute intermittent porphyria?
questions.solution:
Thiopentone cannot be administered in a patient with acute intermittent porphyria.

Thiopentone is a barbiturate that induces aminolevulinic acid synthetase, which increases the formation of porphyrins. This will precipitate porphyria attacks, especially acute intermittent porphyria or variegate porphyria in susceptible individuals.

Other effects of thiopentone are

  • Thiopentone is cerebroprotective as it reduces CSF volume by facilitating its absorption. 
  • decreases cerebral blood flow, and cerebral blood volume thus aiding in lowering intracranial pressure.
  • should be avoided in hypovolemic or shock patients because of the significant reduction in cardiac output (69%) and arterial blood pressure due to vasodilation and venous pooling.
  • produces dose-related central respiratory depression, producing a characteristic ventilatory pattern called 'double apnea'.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man reported that he washes his hands 15-20 times a day, to the point of it taking a toll on his workplace performance. He says this is due to repetitive thoughts that his hands are contaminated with dirt. What is the most probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The man is suffering from obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), as evidenced by the obsession (doubt that his hands are contaminated), followed by a compulsion (washing his hands way too many times). An obsession with contamination is a common symptom of adult OCD.

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) comprises symptoms that include intrusive thoughts, ritu­als, preoccupations, and compulsions. These recurrent obses­sions or compulsions cause severe distress to the patient. The patient might have an obsession, a compulsion, or both.

The recurrent and intrusive thoughts, feelings, ideas, and sensations are referred to as obsessions. A compulsion is a conscious, standardized, recurrent behavior, eg: counting, and checking, and is done in order to reduce the anxiety associated with the obsession.

Treatment of OCD includes:

  • Pharmacotherapy: SSRIs or clomipramine
  • Behavioural therapy: Approaches include:
    • exposure and response prevention
    • desensitization
    • thought stopping
    • flooding
    • implosion therapy
    • aversive conditioning

A combination of behavioural and pharmacotherapy is most effective.

Other options:

Option A: Bipolar disorder is a mood disorder characterized by alternating episodes of mania or hypomania and depression. It can affect daily functioning, with symptoms ranging from elevated energy and impulsivity to sadness and fatigue.

Option C: Schizophrenia is a chronic mental disorder characterized by hallucinations, delusions, disorganized thinking, and impaired functioning. It typically manifests in early adulthood and affects perception, emotion, and behaviour.

Option D: Mania is a state of elevated mood, increased energy, and hyperactivity, often seen in bipolar disorder. It can lead to impulsivity, reduced need for sleep, and impaired judgment.

questions.text: Split thickness skin graft for wound closure on thigh includes:

choices.text: Epidermis and variable parts of dermis

questions.solution:
Split thickness skin graft for wound closure on thigh includes epidermis and variable parts of the dermis.

Split thickness skin graft (Thiersch graft ): Partial-thickness skin grafts consisting of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis are called split-thickness skin grafts.

Full-thickness skin grafts (Wolfe graft): include the epidermis and entire dermis, with portions of the sweat glands, sebaceous glands, and hair follicles. 

Advantages of split skin graft over full-thickness skin graft:

  • Large grafts can be harvested.
  • In the case of thinner split-thickness grafts, the donor site heals more rapidly and can be reused in severe cases such as burns.
  • Uptake is good. Meshing can be done i.e. small splits are made in graft and any exudates collected can come out through this and this improves graft take up. 
  • Meshing also allows the graft to expand.

Advantages of full-thickness skin graft over split skin graft:

  • It has a lesser degree of post graft contraction
  • Best cosmetic appearance as they include the highest number of skin appendage elements.

The most preferable donor site is buttock in cosmetically sensitive individuals and children. The most commonly used donor site is the thigh.

  • The graft is taken from the donor site with a handheld Humby knife or electric dermatome.
  • Grafts are perforated to allow exudates to escape and improve ‘take’. It can further be meshed to allow expansion.
  • Grafts will take up only on the beds which are vascularized, hence preparation of wound bed is an essential step.
  • Skin grafts are completely dependent on nutrition on the tissue over which they are placed and can heal well over muscle, perichondrium, and periosteum. They do not take well over bone or cartilage or on tissue that has been irradiated or infected or is hypovascular.
  • A clean healthy wound bed with a meshed graft tied in place to stop movement will encourage take.
  • The presence of group A beta-hemolytic streptococci is a contraindication in grafting as it can destroy split grafts completely and also convert donors to full-thickness defects.
  • The donor area is dressed appropriately and the dressing is opened after 10 days and not earlier. 

The given image shows Humby's knife. The average thickness of the graft obtained from a Humbys knife is 0.3 mm.

Related Pearl: Skin graft : phases of uptake of the graft

The take of skin graft occurs in three phases:

  1. Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): during the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from host bed capillaries.
  2. Inosculation, in which cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses
  3. Neovascularization, in which blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft

Sensibility returns to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, with light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition,revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced by postgraft day 7 with fibroblasts)

questions.text: A patient is brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident. The patient is in respiratory distress and has visibly dilated neck veins. A large amount of air was noted on the left side in the X-ray as shown below. What is the next best step of management?

choices.text: Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th intercostal space

questions.solution:
The given X-ray features and clinical scenario point towards the diagnosis of tension pneumothorax. The next best step in the management is wide bore needle insertion in the 5th intercostal space.

The chest X-ray shows a well-demarcated area devoid of lung markings on the left side with tracheal deviation and the mediastinal shift to the right side. Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, and treatment should never be delayed while waiting for radiological confirmation. Imaging modalities used are ultrasound – extended focused assessment with sonar for trauma (eFAST), chest x-ray, and spiral CT.

A tension pneumothorax develops when there is a tear either in the parietal or visceral pleura. This tear acts as a one-way valve i.e. air enters from the lung or chest wall through it during inspiration but has no way to escape during expiration. This ultimately leads to the collapse of the affected lung.

It usually occurs following penetrating or blunt chest trauma, iatrogenic lung injury, or mechanical positive pressure ventilation.

It is characterized by:

  • Chest pain
  • Tachypnoea, and acute dyspnea
  • Sudden onset hemodynamic compromise (tachycardia, hypotension, low O2 saturation, loss of consciousness)
  • Neck vein distention
  • Tracheal deviation away from the side of injury 
  • Decreased chest movements on the affected side
  • Hyper-resonance on percussion on the affected side
  • Absence or decreased breath sounds on the affected side

The X-ray below shows a left-sided tension pneumothorax. There is a large, well-demarcated area devoid of lung markings on the left side. The yellow arrows are pointing to the tracheal deviation and the mediastinal shift to the right side.

Management of tension pneumothorax:

  • Immediate management- needle decompression or needle thoracostomy i.e. insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line
  • Definitive management- tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety identified as a triangle that lies anterior to the midaxillary line above the nipple, below, and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.

The images below show the triangle of safety and technique of chest drain insertion.

Other options:

  • Pericardiocentesis is done in cases of cardiac tamponade which is characterized by the presence of hypotension, distended jugular veins, and muffled heart sounds (Beck's triad). The breath sounds are absent in tension pneumothorax while they are present in cardiac tamponade.
  • Surgery for pneumothorax can be performed by video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) or as an open procedure (thoracotomy) in cases of spontaneous pneumothorax failing to settle despite chest drainage. Pleural adhesion is achieved by chemical pleurodesis where talc is used and is insufflated into the chest cavity.

questions.text: A patient who is a tour guide on Mount Everest presented with blisters on her hand as shown in the figure below. She has severe pain and on examination is erythematous and tender. Which of the following is not used in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Apply heat to the area and cast as soon as possible

questions.solution:
The diagnosis in this patient is frostbite. Management does not involve the application of heat to the area and cast, as it is contraindicated in frostbite.

In frostbite, tissue damage results from severe environmental cold exposure or from direct contact with a very cold object. Tissue injury results from both freezing and vascular stasis. It usually affects the distal aspects of the extremities or exposed parts of the face, such as the ears, nose, chin, and cheeks.

Clinical features include decreased sensation (especially for pain, and temperature sensations) in the acral tips and extremities. The affected area appears waxy, mottled, or violaceous. Patients may have a wood-like sensation in the affected area.

Treatment:

  • Initial treatment is by rapid rewarming (or thawing), which is accomplished by immersion of the affected part in a water bath at temperatures of 37°–40°C (99°–104°F) for 30–60 min. Rewarming by exercise, rubbing, or friction is not advised. 
  • Analgesics such as ibuprofen are often required during rewarming.
  • Antithrombotics, thrombolytics, and vasodilators such as prostacyclin can be given to improve circulation after rewarming.
  • Frost bites are associated with an increased risk of infections and tetanus. Therefore, the injured area should be cleaned with soap or antiseptic, and sterile dressings should be applied. Tetanus prophylaxis must be given, but, empirical antibiotics are not recommended.
  • The patient must be monitored for the development of compartment syndrome.
  • Elective late amputation after imaging may be required in severe cases.

questions.text: What is the cause of lactational amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
The cause of lactational amenorrhea is increased prolactin secretion as a result of the baby sucking at the mother's breast.

Lactational amenorrhea:

  • Type of secondary amenorrhea due to the effect of prolactin secretion.
  • During lactation, there are pulsatile bursts of prolactin secretion in response to suckling.
  • Prolactin suppresses GnRH, LH, and FSH causing lactational amenorrhea.
  • Regular lactation with one feed at night delays ovulation and pregnancy for up to 6 months, provided she remains amenorrhoeic.
  • After 6 months, lactation has no bearing on ovulation and pregnancy can occur, despite amenorrhoea and might need other forms of contraception.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man living in Nellore, Andhra Pradesh presents with the following lesions on his teeth. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image along with the endemic area of Andhra Pradesh is diagnostic of Dental fluorosis.

Dental fluorosis (also termed mottled enamel) is an extremely common disorder, characterized by hypomineralization of tooth enamel caused by ingestion of excessive fluoride during enamel formation.

Fluorosis occurs when drinking water contains excess amounts of fluorine, in the range of 3-5mg/L. It is endemic in parts of India- Andhra Pradesh (Nellore, Nalgonda, Prakasam), Punjab, Haryana, Karnataka, Kerala, Tamil Nadu. 

Mechanism:

  • In the extra-cellular environment of maturing enamel, an excess of fluoride ions alters the rate at which enamel matrix proteins (amelogenin) are enzymatically broken down and the rate at which the subsequent breakdown products are removed.
  • Fluoride may also indirectly alter the action of protease via a decrease in the availability of free calcium ions in the mineralization environment.
  • This results in the formation of enamel with less mineralization.
  • This hypomineralized enamel has altered optical properties and appears opaque and lustreless relative to normal enamel.

Classification:

The two main classification systems which are used in the grading of severity of dental fluorosis are Dean’s system and TF system.

Symptoms correspond to levels of fluoride intake:

  • Dental fluorosis: (1.5mg/L) Occurs if excess fluoride is ingested during the period of tooth calcification, i.e. in the first 7 years of life. Best seen on the upper incisors and almost exclusively affects only permanent teeth. It causes mottling on dental enamel, the appearance of chalky-white patches on the teeth, and loss of shine in the early stages. The white spots progressively turn yellow and can even become brown-black. The loss of enamel gives a corroded appearance. 
  • Skeletal fluorosis: (3-6mg/L) Occurs due to the heavy deposition of fluoride in the skeleton. Fluorosis stimulates osteoblastic activity, fluorapatite crystals are laid down in bone and these are usually resistant to secondary osteoclastic resorption. This leads to calcium retention, osteosclerosis, and osteophytosis. Ossification of ligaments and fascial attachments is characteristic.
  • Crippling fluorosis: (>10mg/L) Can lead to permanent disability. 

Genu valgum and osteoporosis of the lower limb are seen in a newer form of fluorosis in Tamil Nadu and Andhra Pradesh. It is seen in people consuming jawar (sorghum), as it promotes greater retention of ingested fluoride.

Interventions for Fluorosis 

  • Change the drinking water source with a lower fluoride content (0.5 to 0.8 mg/L). Running surface water contains lower quantities of fluorides than groundwater sources.
  • Chemical treatment in a water treatment plant can be moderately expensive. The National Environmental Engineering Research Institute, Nagpur developed a technique for removing fluoride by a chemical treatment called the Nalgonda technique. 
  • Fluoride supplements should not be prescribed for children who drink fluoridated water.
  • The use of fluoride toothpaste in areas of endemic fluorosis is not recommended for children up to 6 years of age

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented with a 1-week history of yellow skin and sclerae but is otherwise asymptomatic. He gives a history of viral infection 10 days ago which resolved 2 days back. There is a history of a similar episode of icterus 2 years back when the patient had long hours of basketball practice. The current serum bilirubin is 2.4 mg/dL, unconjugated bilirubin is 2.1mg/dl, and conjugated bilirubin is 0.3mg/dl. Serum AST and ALT levels are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Gilbert syndrome is the most likely diagnosis in this patient.

This patient's mild jaundice seen only during a period of stress along with an increase in unconjugated bilirubin and normal AST, and ALT levels strongly point towards a diagnosis of Gilbert syndrome.

Gilbert syndrome is a benign, familial disorder inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern characterized by mild intermittent jaundice usually seen during stress, illnesses, or any other precipitating factors. There is no hemolysis or underlying liver disease. The condition is recognized to arise from a mutation in the promoter region of the UGT1A1 gene, which results in mildly decreased UDP-Glucoronyltransferase production. UDP-Glucoronyltransferase is required for the conjugation of bilirubin.

Precipitating factors in Gilbert syndrome:

  • Dehydration
  • Fasting
  • Menstrual periods
  • Illness
  • Vigorous exercise.

Other options:

Option A: Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a benign autosomal recessive disease that is characterized by chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and conspicuous brown-black melanin-like pigment deposition in the liver. The disease is caused due to mutation in multidrug resistance protein 2 (MRP-2) in hepatocytes, which is required for the transport of non-bile salt organic anions at the canalicular membranes. Liver biopsy shows characteristic deposition of black-colored pigment.

Option B: Crigler-Najjar syndrome is of two types with type 1 having absent/trace UDP-Glucoronyltransferase production and type 2 having <10% of the normal enzyme activity. Hence, type 1 is far more severe and leads to kernicterus and neurological damage in babies. Type 2 may also lead to kernicterus occasionally. Unconjugated bilirubin is elevated. Isolated unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia in a 25-year-old male is less likely to be due to Criggler Najar type 1 syndrome. It is because patients usually die in infancy or early childhood despite the best treatment.

Option D: Rotor syndrome: similar to Dubin-Johnson syndrome but with a milder presentation. Increased conjugated bilirubin levels. Liver biopsy does not show black colored liver

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presented with a skin lesion as shown below. Biopsy shows the presence of multiple neutrophilic foci in the stratum corneum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image represents plaque psoriasis. The characteristic histopathological finding in psoriasis consists of multiple neutrophilic foci in the parakeratotic stratum corneum i.e Munro’s microabscesses and spongiform neutrophils in the spinous layer of the epidermis i.e spongiform pustules of Kogoj.

Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the skin with systemic manifestations. Plaque psoriasis is the most common type. The nails are frequently involved and punctate pitting is the most common finding seen. Psoriasis is associated with Koebner or isomorphic phenomenon. It describes the appearance of new lesions along the site of trauma (linear lesions)

  • The peak on occurrence is between 16 to 22 years and between 57 to 62 years. They usually present with itching and a papulosquamous rash.
  • The lesions are red, scaly, and have well demarcation from the normal skin.
  • They can also be encircled by a clear peripheral zone which is called the Woronoff ring.
  • They commonly appear in the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs.

Topical application of steroids, retinoids, vitamin D, and emollients is the mainstay of management. Phototherapy and oral methotrexate, acitretin, and cyclosporine can also be used.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

questions.text: A  patient was given halothane for a surgical procedure. After few minutes, the anaesthetist noticed that he developed rigidity and hyperthermia. Which of the following ions is the reason for the above symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of rigidity and hyperthermia with halothane suggests the diagnosis of malignant hyperthermia. The ion responsible for it is calcium.

Malignant hyperthermia is a rare genetic hypermetabolic muscle disease, the characteristic signs, and symptoms of which most commonly appear with exposure to inhaled anesthetics or succinylcholine. 

The pathophysiology behind the development of malignant hyperthermia is that there is an uncontrolled increase in intracellular calcium in skeletal muscle. The sudden release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum removes the inhibition of troponin, resulting in sustained muscle contraction. Markedly increased ATPase activity results in an uncontrolled hypermetabolic state with significantly increased oxygen consumption & CO2 production, producing severe lactic acidosis and hyperthermia. 

Related Pearl: Malignant hyperthermia key features

Pathophysiology:

  • Prolonged opening of functionally altered ryanodine receptors, leading to uncontrolled release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction.

Drugs known to trigger malignant hyperthermia:

  • Inhaled anesthetics: Halothane, Isoflurane, Sevoflurane, Desflurane, Ether, Methoxyflurane
  • Depolarising muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine

Clinical signs:

  • Increased metabolism: Increased EtCO2, decreased SpO2, metabolic acidosis
  • Increased sympathetic activity: Tachycardia, hypertension, arrythmia
  • Muscle damage: Masseter spasm, generalised rigidity, hyperkalemia, rhabdomyolysis, myoglobinuria
  • Hyperthermia: Fever, sweating

 Treatment: 

  • Discontinuation of all anesthetic agents
  • Hyperventilation with 100% O2
  • Dantrolene: 2.5 mg/kg intravenously every 5 min until the episode is terminated (upper limit - 10 mg/kg).
  • Correction of acid-base, electrolyte abnormality 
  • Cooling the patient

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma is found to have a tumor that is 10 cm in size, situated at the lower pole of the kidney with negative regional lymph nodes. Which of the following is the preferred management for this patient?
questions.solution:
A tumor that is 10 cm in size, confined to the kidney with negative metastasis is classified as T2bN0M0. A tumor greater than 7 cm is managed by radical nephrectomy. RCC is a radio and chemoresistant tumor.

Radical Nephrectomy :

  • Classic radical nephrectomy consists of the removal of the kidney, perirenal fat, adrenal gland, and regional lymph nodes.
  • In patients with a tumor <5 cm in size, located at the inferior pole, the adrenal gland can be spared. 
  • Regional lymph node dissection is done for patients with clinically positive nodes detected by CT or during surgery.

Partial nephrectomy :

  • For tumors less than or equal to 4 cm in size and limited to the kidney (T1a), partial nephrectomy is performed.
  • Partial nephrectomy is also increasingly being performed in tumors >4cm in size but less than or equal to 7 cm, and limited to the kidney (T1b). If partial nephrectomy is not feasible in T1b tumors, then a radical nephrectomy is done.
  • Other indications for partial nephrectomy are bilateral renal cell carcinoma and carcinoma affecting a solitary functioning kidney.

Radical nephrectomy is performed in patients with large tumors and for patients in whom a partial nephrectomy is not technically feasible.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man presents to the emergency department accompanied by police. He came to the police station accusing his daughter of wanting to kill him. The police on investigating the family and the neighbors understood that it was a false accusation. His physical examination is not remarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis here?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario the patient thinks that his daughter wants to kill him which is not true. Since the patient appears normal apart from the delusion, the clinical scenario is likely to be of a delusional disorder, more specifically delusion of persecution. 

Delusion is a false belief, that is firmly held despite objective and obvious contradictory proof. Other members of the culture do not share this belief. It can be present in conditions like schizophrenia, mania, major depressive disorders, and delusional disorders. 

Other options:

Option B: Illusion is an incorrect perception or misinterpretation of a sensory stimulus. Eg: There is a rope in front of you but you see it as a snake.

Option C: Hallucination: Perception in the absence of any stimulus. Eg: There is nothing in front of you but you can see a snake.

Option D: Cotard syndrome is a condition in which an individual feels like they have lost all possessions and status, including their entire being and all internal organs.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: Which of the following peaks marked in the image below is responsible for ovulation ?
questions.solution:
The label marked 2 represents the LH surge ,which is responsible for ovulation.

Phases of the menstrual cycle :

Follicular phase (days 0–14)

  • A primordial follicle develops to the Graafian stage, with atresia of neighboring follicles.
  • LH and FSH receptors are up-regulated in theca and granulosa cells.
  • Estradiol levels increase and cause proliferation of the uterus.
  • FSH and LH levels are suppressed by the negative feedback effect of estradiol on the anterior pituitary.
  • Progesterone levels are low.

Ovulation (day 14)

  • Occurs 14 days before menses, regardless of cycle length. Thus, in a 28-day cycle, ovulation occurs on day 14; in a 35-day cycle, ovulation occurs on day 22.
  • A burst of estradiol synthesis at the end of the follicular phase has a positive feedback effect on the secretion of FSH and LH (LH surge).
  • Ovulation occurs as a result of the estrogen-induced LH surge.
  • Estrogen levels decrease just after ovulation (but rise again during the luteal phase).
  • Cervical mucus increases in quantity; it becomes less viscous and more penetrable by sperm.

Luteal phase (days 14–28)

  • Progesterone levels are high.
  • The corpus luteum begins to develop, and it synthesizes estrogen and progesterone. Vascularity and secretory activity of the endometrium increase to prepare for receipt of a fertilized egg.
  • Basal body temperature increases because of the effect of progesterone on the hypothalamic thermoregulatory center.
  • If fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum regresses at the end of the luteal phase. As a result, estradiol and progesterone levels decrease abruptly.

Menses (days 0–4)

  • The endometrium is sloughed because of the abrupt withdrawal of estradiol and progesterone.

questions.text: Which of the following fertility indicator can change with changes in age-specific mortality rates?
questions.solution:
Net reproduction rate can change with changes in age-specific mortality rates. General fertility rate, total fertility rate and gross reproduction rate are not dependent on age-specific mortality rate.

Net Reproduction Rate: The number of daughters a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age-specific fertility and mortality rates.

Related Pearl: Fertility Indicators

Crude birth rate

  • It is the simplest measure of fertility although its usage is unsatisfactory
  • India, as per SRS bulletin 2018, had a birth rate of 20.0 per 1000 population

General Fertility Rate

  • It is a better indicator of fertility than crude birth rate
  • The demerit of this indicator is that not all women in the denominator are exposed to childbirth

Age-specific fertility rates is a more precise measure of fertility and is also a sensitive indicator of family planning achievement.

Total Fertility Rate

  • It is the sum of all age-specific fertility rates multiplied by 5
  • This measure gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size

Gross Reproductive Rate is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality.

Net Reproduction Rate

  • It is a demographic indicator
  • NRR of 1 is equivalent to approximately the 2 child norm
  • If the NRR is less than 1, then the reproductive performance of the population is said to be inadequate

questions.text: A 22-year-old college student presents with small depigmented lesions which have been there for over 2 years now as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image is suggestive of vitiligo. The pathological basis of vitiligo is the loss of melanocytes.

Vitiligo is a common form of localized depigmentation. It is characterized by milky‐white sharply demarcated macules. It is an acquired condition resulting from the autoimmune destruction of dopa-positive melanocytes in the basal layer of the epidermis.

Vitiligo can begin at any age but in the majority of cases becomes apparent in the third decade. The prevalence is most probably the same in both sexes or a slight female preponderance.

Electron microscopy studies confirm the loss of melanocytes. Wood's lamp examination shows milky-white fluorescence.

Koebner phenomenon defined as the development of lesions at sites of trauma to uninvolved skin of patients with cutaneous diseases is a well‐known phenomenon in vitiligo.

World Vitiligo day is celebrated every year on 25th June to promote understanding and help vitiligo patients avoid discrimination and become more optimistic in life. The theme for the year 2021 is "Embracing Life with Vitiligo".

Other options:

Option A: Melasma is the most common cause of facial melanosis that manifests as hyperpigmented macules on the face. It is exacerbated by sun exposure and oral contraceptive pills. The condition is predominantly seen in females

Option C: Psoriasis: The peak occurrence is between 16 to 22 years and between 57 to 62 years. They usually present with itching and a papulosquamous rash. The lesions are red, and scaly, and have well demarcation from the normal skin. They can also be encircled by a clear peripheral zone which is called the Woronoff ring. They commonly appear in the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs.

Option D: Dermatitis herpetiformis is a chronic, intensely pruritic, skin condition associated with gluten‐sensitive enteropathy. It typically appears in the 4th decade,  most typically over the extensor surfaces of the elbows, knees, buttocks, and scalp. On examination, multiple erythematous papules and vesicles can be seen over the extensor aspects. They appear symmetrical and heal without scarring. The oral cavity may show mucosal abnormalities and enamel pits.

questions.text: A young male who had a road traffic accident is brought to the emergency department. His left leg is shortened, internally rotated, and adducted. On examination, femoral artery pulsation is not felt. A plain radiograph of his hip was taken which is shown below. What is your diagnosis?

choices.text: Fracture neck of femur with injury to femoral vessels
Anterior dislocation of hip with femoral artery injury

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of posterior hip dislocation. In this condition, the leg will be in flexion, adduction, and internal rotation. 

Posterior hip dislocation is the commonest type of hip dislocation accounting for about 80%  of the cases. It is commonly seen following dashboard injuries. The patient presents with flexion, adduction, and an internal rotation deformity.

Radiological findings include femoral head lying above and behind the acetabulum, femoral head appearing smaller than normal, lesser trochanter not visualized as the thigh is internally rotated and the femoral head and posterior acetabular wall fractures may also be seen

Sciatic nerve injury is seen in 10-20 % of cases with posterior hip dislocation. It is usually a neuropraxia type of injury and resolves spontaneously. The femoral artery pulsation is usually felt against the neck of the femur. Due to the posterior dislocation of the hip joint, the femoral vessels fall backwards and the pulsation of the femoral artery cannot be felt. This is called the vascular sign of Narath.

Anterior hip dislocation is less common than posterior hip dislocations and accounts for about 10-20% of all hip dislocations. This injury is usually sustained following a high-energy accident. The affected limb in this condition will be abducted, externally rotated, and slightly flexed.

Note: Although, vascular injuries are seen in posterior dislocations as well, they are most likely with anterior dislocation. This is because of the femoral artery lying anterior to the head

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents to you with limitation of abduction and internal rotation of the left hip. The X-ray appearance of his left hip joint is shown in the below image. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and trethowan's sign seen in the x-ray are suggestive of slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE).

The Klein line is a line along the superior aspect of the femoral neck which normally intersects the epiphysis. In SCFE, Klein's line does not intersect the epiphysis and passes superior to it. This is known as Trethowan's sign.

Slipped femoral capital epiphysis (SCFE) occurs during a period of rapid growth with the average age of presentation around 12 years.

Risk factors: Obesity, hypothyroidism, growth hormone excess, and chronic renal failure are all-important associations of SCFE.

Clinical features:

  • Patients with SCFE typically present in the rapid growth phase of adolescence with pain in the thigh, groin, or knee.
  • On examination, the affected limb is shortened and externally rotated.
  • There is a limitation in abduction, flexion, and internal rotation on the affected side.
  • Flexion of the hip might lead to obligate external rotation and abduction - positive Drehmann’s sign.
  • Patients may have an antalgic or Trendelenburg gait.

Other radiological findings include:

  • Wide or irregular physis with loss of the anterior head-neck concavity
  • Sharp metaphyseal border of the head
  • Loss of total epiphyseal height
  • Steel sign (Metaphyseal blanch sign) - The posteriorly displaced femoral epiphysis overlaps over the metaphysis causing a crescent-shaped area of increased density on the AP radiograph.
  • Capener’s sign –the metaphysis displaces laterally, worsening the slip and causes a reduction in the double-density crescent created by the overlap of the posterior acetabulum and proximal metaphysis on the AP radiograph.
  • Southwick angle – The angle between the line drawn perpendicular to the physis and a line parallel to the femoral shaft. As slip worsens, the Southwick angle will increase. It is measured on the frog lateral X-ray view.

Other options:

Perthes disease:

It is characterized by idiopathic avascular necrosis of the proximal femoral epiphysis. This condition commonly affects children of 4-8 years of age. The child has pain in the hip while performing passive movements. The radiograph shows features of bone necrosis followed by remodeling.

Developmental Dysplasia of the hip: It is characterized by spontaneous dislocation of the hip joint before, during, or shortly after birth. This condition is more common in females. Children with this condition have a waddling gait and on examination abduction and lateral rotation of the hip are decreased. X-ray shows a broken Shenton's line and the femoral head lies in the upper and outer quadrants formed by Hilgenreiner’s line and Perkin’s line.

The image given below shows the vertical Perkin's line and the horizontal Hilgenreiner's line. Normally the femoral head lies in the inner and lower quadrant formed by these lines. But in DDH the femoral head is in the upper and outer quadrant.

Ankylosing spondylitis: It is a chronic progressive inflammatory condition affecting the sacroiliac joints and the axial skeleton. It is commonly seen in young male adults and they typically present with an insidious onset back pain that improves with exercise. The earliest radiological finding is erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints and the characteristic late sign is the bamboo-spine appearance.

questions.text: A 53-year-old  patient was brought to the emergency room with altered sensorium and rapid shallow breathing. His abdomen is distended with palpable hepatomegaly and splenomegaly and sclerae are icteric. The other examination findings are given below. Laboratory tests show that the AST: ALT ratio is 3:1. What is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient with the presentation of altered consciousness, jaundice (scleral icterus), and signs of liver cirrhosis (distended abdomen, hepatomegaly), spider naevi, Terry nails, and the characteristic AST>ALT is suggestive of alcoholic liver disease.

In alcoholic liver disease, usually the AST: ALT > 2:1. This is because there is a deficiency of pyridoxal 5'- phosphate in alcoholics. Pyridoxal 5'-phosphate is a cofactor for the enzymatic activity of ALT. Therefore, ALT levels fail to rise while AST levels increase. An AST: ALT ratio >2:1 is suggestive, whereas a ratio >3:1 (as in this patient)  is highly suggestive, of alcoholic liver disease.

Normal levels:

  • Aspartate transaminase (AST) - 10-40 IU/L
  • Alanine transaminase (ALT) - 10-40 IU/L

Other options:

Option B: In acute viral hepatitis, the aminotransferases are often elevated > 500 IU (400-4000 IU/L) due to extensive cell injury.

Option C: In autoimmune hepatitis, aminotransferase levels are elevated and fluctuate in the range of 100-1000 IU/L. Autoimmune hepatitis may present as acute or chronic hepatitis or cirrhosis. Commonly associated symptoms include fatigue, anorexia, pruritis, arthralgias, upper abdominal discomfort, and skin rashes including acne among others. 

Option D: Acute acetaminophen poisoning (paracetamol tablets ingestion).In acute acetaminophen poisoning, the aminotransferases are elevated > 1000 IU and may exceed 10,000 IU/L due to acute hepatocellular injury.

questions.text: What is the ideal time and method of removing hair before surgery to avoid surgical site infection?

choices.text: On the OT table with electric hair clippers
With a razor 24 hours before surgery
With a hair removal cream on the previous day
On the OT table with a razor

questions.solution:
To avoid surgical site infection, hair should be removed on the OT table with electric hair clippers. 

Measures to decrease the incidence of surgical site infections (SSIs)

Patient preparation:

1) Smoking cessation four to six weeks prior to elective surgery is recommended to decrease the incidence of pulmonary complications. 

2) Bowel preparation prior to abdominal surgeries is expected to decrease the incidence of SSIs.

Infection control:

1) Timely administration of preoperative antimicrobial prophylaxis.

2) All surgical team members must practice appropriate surgical hand hygiene measures.

3) Surgeons and other team members within the premises of the operation theater should routinely wear barrier clothing such as scrubs, caps, and gowns.

4) Preoperatively, the patient must be advised to use topical mupirocin and bathe with chlorhexidine to aid in Staphylococcus aureus decolonization.

5) Shaving hair with razors at the operative site is not advised. If hair removal is absolutely necessary, it may be performed with hair clippers.

Miscellaneous perioperative measures:

1) Maintain normothermic OT

2) Ensure laminar airflow

3) Minimise red cell transfusions

4) Ensure adequate glycemic control.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with severe dysmenorrhoea, dyspareunia and infertility. A diagnosis of endometriosis was made and she was posted for laparoscopy surgery. During the procedure,  dense pelvic adhesions were seen with the bowel stuck to the fundus and cystic ovaries stuck to each other. What is the next step in managing this patient?

choices.text: Gestrinone to decrease the LH surge

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of endometriosis and the next step in the management of this patient is cystectomy and adhesiolysis. 

After the surgery the patient is advised to start infertility treatment too.

Medical management of endometriosis:

  • Gestrinone is an anti-estrogenic, anti-progestational, and mildly anabolic drug that reduces sex-hormone-binding globulin to release free testosterone. It also decreases the LH surge. It causes regression of lesions and amenorrhea. It is a 19-nortestosterone derivative similar to danazol, but with fewer side effects. 
  • Combined oral contraceptives are used for symptom control and alleviate disease. These also cause menstrual cycle regulation and delay pregnancy. 
  • Oral progestogens exert an anti-estrogenic effect and cause decidualization and endometrial atrophy. This causes disease regression. It doesn't prevent ovulation, thus is suitable for women who are trying to conceive. 
  • Mirena IUCDs reduce dysmenorrhea and menorrhagia. It is a single-sitting treatment with minimal side effects. 
  • Aromatase inhibitors like letrozole are anti-estrogens given for disease regression. 
  • Anti-inflammatory drugs like mefenamic acid and naproxen relieve dysmenorrhea.

Therapeutic procedures:

  • Aspiration of Peritoneal fluid from the cul-de-sac removes PGE2, relieves dysmenorrhea, pelvic pain, and improves fertility 
  • Destruction of endometriotic lesions <3cm with diathermy, Nd-YAG laser or CO2 vaporization can be attempted. 
  • Larger lesions and chocolate cysts can be excised. 
  • Cystectomy can be done for pelvic pain but can reduce fertility potential. 
  • Laparoscopic breaking of adhesions relieves dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain. It also restores tubal patency and improves ovulation. Pre-sacral neurectomy can be done simultaneously.. 
  • Laser uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA) is done for pelvic pain.

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.

Primary assessment (i.e the primary survey) follows the ABCDE pattern: Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability (neurologic status), and Exposure. It is crucial to realize that the absence of abdominal pain or tenderness does not rule out the presence of significant intra-abdominal injury.

  • Concomitant femur fracture

Bedside ultrasound (US) focuses on dependent intraperitoneal sites where blood is most likely to accumulate: the hepatorenal space (Morison's pouch), the splenorenal recess, and the inferior portion of the peritoneal cavity (including pouch of Douglas). These studies, when combined with an evaluation of the pericardium are referred to as the FAST exam (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma).

questions.text: What is the most common cause of death in the case of esophageal varices in a patient with liver cirrhosis?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of death in esophageal varices in a patient with liver cirrhosis is hypovolemic shock due to variceal bleed/hemorrhage.

Hypovolemic shock is the most common type of shock and to some degree is a component of all other types of shock.

Shock is defined as a systemic state of low tissue perfusion which is inadequate for normal cellular respiration.

Shock can be classified as follows:

Shock Inciting mechanism
Hypovolemic shock

Reduced circulating blood volume

(eg., hemorrhage, dehydration)
Cardiogenic shock

Failure of the cardiac pump

(eg., myocardial infarction, cardiac dysrhythmias)
Obstructive shock

Mechanical obstruction of cardiac filling 

(eg., cardiac tamponade, tension pneumothorax)
Distributive shock

Systemic vasodilation leading to organ hypoperfusion

(eg., anaphylaxis due to histamine release, sepsis due to the release of bacterial products, spinal cord injury due to sympathetic failure)
Endocrine shock

Combination of hypovolemic, cardiogenic or distributive shock.

(eg., hypo and hyperthyroidism, adrenal insufficiency)

questions.text: On being asked "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?" the patient replies "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa." What is this type of response known as?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is tangentiality. The patient has given a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly; it is tangential. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

 Tangentiality is a formal thought disorder.

Symptom Description
Circumstantiality Overinclusion of trivial or irrelevant details that impede the sense of getting to the point
Clang associations Thoughts are associated by the sound of words rather than by their meaning (e.g., through rhyming or assonance)

Derailment

(loose associations)

 A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.
Flight of ideas A succession of multiple associations so that thoughts seem to move abruptly from idea to idea; often (but not invariably) expressed through rapid, pressured speech.
Neologism The invention of new words or phrases or the use of conventional words in idiosyncratic ways.
Perseveration Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas.
Tangentiality In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic without actually answering the question
Thought blocking A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas.

Related Pearl: Classification of disorders of thought

questions.text: A patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy and was discharged after removing the drain tube on the first postoperative day. On day two, he came back to the hospital with complaints of increasing abdominal pain and fever. On ultrasound examination, there was a 5 x 5 cm collection in the subhepatic space. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation suggests a bile duct injury following laparoscopic cholecystectomy leading to a bile leak. 

Bile duct injury

  • Usually is manifested in the postoperative period
  • Clinical features
    • Fever
    • Increasing abdominal pain
    • Jaundice
    • Bile leakage from an incision

Diagnosis

Imaging: Ultrasonography

  • To assess for a fluid collection and to evaluate the biliary tree 

Treatment strategy

  • Control of infection, limiting inflammation
    • Percutaneous drainage of periportal fluid collections
    • Parenteral antibiotics
  • Clear and thorough delineation of the entire biliary anatomy
    • Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) or percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC)
    • Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), especially if a cystic-duct stump leak is suspected
  • Reestablishment of biliary-enteric continuity (surgery)
    1. Tension-free, mucosa-to-mucosa anastomosis
    2. Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy

 Option A: Infection is very unlikely to present in the immediate postoperative period with a pus collection of 5x5cms particularly after laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

Option B: Surgical site pain will not be severe and diffuse instead it is localized and bearable.

Option D: Retained gallstones are very unlikely.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lactating mother presents with pain in her left breast and a fever. On examination, the left breast appears as shown in the image below. There is mild axillary lymphadenopathy on the affected side and the other breast looks healthy. Repeated aspirations under antibiotic cover were unsuccessful. Ultrasound showed fluid collection. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario points towards a diagnosis of breast abscess. The latest guidelines for the management of breast abscesses specify that multiple aspirations under antibiotic cover should be attempted before an incision and drainage are done. This often allows resolution without the need for an incision scar and also allows the patient to continue breastfeeding. But her aspirations have been unsuccessful and thus incision and drainage have to be the next step in the management of this patient.

Mastitis occurs due to the growth of staphylococcus or streptococcus due to breast milk stasis. This occurs secondary to blockage of the lactiferous duct or due to incomplete emptying of breast milk or due to a retracted nipple. Overgrowth of these bacteria results in the development of breast abscesses.

It is commoner in new mothers at the beginning of lactation who are inexperienced with breastfeeding or during weaning when nipple trauma occurs due to the infant's growing teeth. 

Signs and symptoms of this condition involve:

  • Fever and malaise
  • Localized pain and tenderness 
  • Redness and swelling of the affected breast
  • Fluctuation test positive due to pus in the abscess. It is a late sign.

The initial treatment should involve providing pain relief with analgesics. The abscess should then be localized preferably under USG guidance and percutaneous aspiration carried out. The pus should be sent for microbiological examination to find the organism and antibiotic sensitivity. Repeated aspirations may be carried out under antibiotics cover if needed.

In some conditions mentioned below, the breast abscess may be unresponsive to repeated aspirations and antibiotic cover. In such cases, incision and drainage are performed. The conditions include:

  • Presence of thick pus
  • Bacteria resistant to antibiotics
  • If just a superficial part has been aspirated in the presence of a multiloculated abscess
  • A non-healing breast abscess due to tuberculosis of the breast or inflammatory carcinoma of the breast, or an immunocompromised host.

questions.text: A patient was asked to copy the face of a clock and his drawing is shown below. What is the correct term to be used here?
questions.solution:
Hemispatial neglect is the inability to report, respond, or orient to stimuli in one-half of the space despite having no motor or sensory deficits. 

A patient with neglect is asked to draw a clock, their drawing might show only the numbers 12 to 6, or all 12 numbers might be on one half of the clock face with the other half distorted or blank, like the image shown in the image below.

Neglect patients may also ignore the contralesional side of their body; for instance, they might only shave, or apply makeup to, the non-neglected side. These patients may frequently collide with objects or structures such as door frames on the side being neglected.

Other options:

Option A: Confabulation is a phenomenon in which the patient fills in memory gaps with inaccurate information. Further investigating the statement made by the patients may reflect past experiences or bizarre, fantastic stories.  This fabrication of false information is not done on purpose.

Option C: Astrexis/Flapping tremor is a type of negative myoclonus characterized by irregular lapses of the posture of various body parts. Mostly associated with hepatic encephalopathy.

Option D: Apraxia: Inability to perform a movement or task when asked despite having the desire and physical capability to carry it out.

Types of apraxia:

  1. Kinetic: Inability to execute the fine acquired motor movement, the lesion is in the precentral cortex.
  2. Ideomotor: Fails to perform on command. The lesion is in the parietal lobe.
  3. Constructional: liability to reproduce simple geometric figures by drawing. The lesion is in the pathway between the occipital or parietal area.
  4. Ideational: Loss of ability to formulate an ideational plan for the execution of the complex act. The lesion is in the dominant parietal lobe.

questions.text: A woman presented in her 8th week of pregnancy seeking MTP. The appropriate dosage of Misoprostol (administered by mucosal route) would be ______
questions.solution:
The dosage of Misoprostol (administered by mucosal route) in this case is 800 mcg.
Mucosal misoprostol administration has increased efficacy and minimizes gastrointestinal side effects and is now preferred over the prior oral administration. The mucosal route includes buccal, sublingual, and vaginal Misoprostol administration.

Medical management protocol for induced abortion for < 12 weeks of gestation (as per WHO 2018 guideline):

  • Combined Regimen (Recommended): 200 mg of oral Mifepristone followed 1-2 days later by 800 mcg of buccal, vaginal, or sublingual Misoprostol
  • Misoprostol-only regimen (Alternative): 800 μg misoprostol administered vaginally, sublingually, or buccally.

Outpatient medical abortion is an acceptable option for pregnancies with a menstrual age < 63 days (9 weeks).

First trimester:

Mifepristone/misoprostol combined regimen (recommended): 200 mg of oral Mifepristone followed 1-2 days later by 800 mcg of buccal, vaginal, or sublingual Misoprostol

Misoprostol-only regimen (alternative): 800 μg misoprostol administered vaginally, sublingually, or buccally.

Methotrexate/misoprostol:

(d) Methotrexate, 50 mg/m2 body surface area intramuscularly or orally; followed in 3-7 days by:

(e) Misoprostol, 800 mcg vaginally. Repeat if needed 1 week after methotrexate initially given
Second trimester:

Mifepristone/misoprostol combined regimen (recommended): 200 mg of oral Mifepristone followed 1-2 days later by 400 mcg of buccal, vaginal, or sublingual Misoprostol every 3 hours

Misoprostol alone (alternative): 400 mcg of buccal, vaginal, or sublingual Misoprostol every 3 hours

Dinoprostone: 20 mg vaginal suppository every 4 hr

Concentrated oxytocin:

50 units oxytocin in 500 mL of normal saline infused during 3 hr; then 1-hr diuresis (no oxytocin); then escalate sequentially in a similar fashion through 150, 200, 250, and finally 300 units oxytocin each in 500 mL normal saline
 

Note: This recommendation has been updated from the WHO 2012 Safe abortion guidance. This updated recommendation applies to pregnancies up to 12 weeks of gestation, whereas, in the prior guidance, different regimens were recommended for pregnancies up to 7 weeks, 9 weeks, and 12 weeks.

Related Pearl: Uses of Misoprostol
