NOTE:

  1. The mucosal route of administration is preferred over the oral route of administration.
  2. The dose suggested in the medical termination of pregnancy also includes incomplete abortion and missed abortion.

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: An immunocompromised patient from a lower-income household presents with mild fever which is present only during the night and associated with weight loss. She has a swelling on her neck as shown in the image below which is soft, and non-tender. The fluctuation test is positive. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of immunosuppression, symptoms of fever at night, weight loss, and the neck finding of an ulcer with undermined edges is suggestive of tubercular lymphadenitis.

The image shows long-standing tubercular adenitis with a sinus. 

Tuberculous cervical lymphadenitis:

  • Any group of lymph nodes can be involved.
  • Symptoms include evening pyrexia, malaise, and cough (from pulmonary tuberculosis) while in children, failure to thrive can be seen. 
  • A matted lymph nodal mass is the typical clinical feature.
  • In later stages the mass may be cystic, denoting an abscess.
  • The abscess denotes underlying caseation and does not show any features of inflammation – hence it is called a 'cold abscess'.
  • The pus is initially confined by the deep cervical fascia, but after weeks or months, this may become eroded at one point and the pus flows through the small opening into the space beneath the superficial fascia. The process has now reached the stage of a ‘collar stud abscess'.
  • An abscess may burst through the skin to form an ulcer with undermined edges which is typical of a tubercular ulcer with undermined edges and can develop into a discharging sinus.
  • Diagnosis is by the culture of pus and biopsy of the lymph node.
  • The involvement of other systems must be excluded.
  • Treatment- antitubercular drugs.

questions.text: A patient who underwent  Nissen's fundoplication was seen in the ward during evening rounds. He is asymptomatic at present with stable vitals. What is the next line of management for this patient?

choices.text: Nasogastric tube to prevent gas bloat syndrome
Insert chest tube to prevent pneumothorax

questions.solution:
The most common complication of Nissen’s fundoplication is a gas-bloat syndrome. So management includes patient vitals monitoring, to see if the patient develops complications.

Fundoplication is a procedure in which the fundus of the stomach is wrapped around the lower end of the esophagus. After this procedure, most patients are unable to belch gas from the stomach into the esophagus. This causes increased gas in the stomach resulting in bloating sensation, abdominal discomfort, and flatulence. This is known as gas bloat syndrome and occurs more commonly with Nissen total fundoplication.

During the early postoperative period, patients who report persistent nausea and demonstrate inadequate intake of a liquid diet should undergo abdominal radiography. If significant gastric distention is identified, a nasogastric tube can safely be placed to decompress the stomach for 24 hours. 

Note:

Pneumothorax is the most common complication that occurs intraoperatively.

questions.text: Pressure greater than __ mm of Hg causes pressure sores.
questions.solution:
External pressure greater than 30 mm of Hg leads to the formation of pressure sores. 

Pressure sores also known as bedsores, pressure ulcers, or decubitus ulcers are defined as tissue necrosis with ulceration due to prolonged pressure. When the external pressure exceeds the capillary occlusive pressure, blood flow ceases leading to tissue anoxia, necrosis, and ulceration. The external pressure when >30mmHg, leads to the formation of pressure sores.

The common sites of pressure sores in decreasing frequency are:

  • Ischium
  • Greater Trochanter
  • Sacrum
  • Heel
  • Malleolus (lateral followed by medial)
  • Occiput

A staging system for description of pressure sores devised by the American National Pressure Ulcer Advisory Panel.

Stage 1 - Non-blanchable erythema without a breach in the epidermis
Stage 2 - Partial-thickness skin loss involving the epidermis and dermis
Stage 3 - Full-thickness skin loss extending into the subcutaneous tissue but not through underlying fascia
Stage 4 - Full-thickness skin loss through fascia with extensive tissue destruction, maybe involving muscle, bone, tendon, or joint

Management:

Prevention is the best treatment for pressure sores. It can be prevented with good skincare, the use of air fluidized beds, special pressure dispersion cushions, or foams. Fecal or urinary diversion can be considered in special cases.

The position of the bedridden patients should be changed once every 2 hours and wheel-chair bound patients should be taught to get off their chairs for 10 seconds every 10 minutes.

Surgical management of pressure sores follows the same principles involved in acute wound treatment. Preoperative, the pressure sores should be adequately debrided and vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) can be used to promote the growth of granulation tissue required for surgical closure. Large skin flaps that have muscle with sensory innervation are best for reconstruction, for example, extensor fascia lata flap with the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh. 

VAC is done by applying intermittent negative pressure of approximately -125mmHg to hasten debridement and promote granulation tissue formation in chronic wounds and ulcers. Negative pressure decreases edema, removes interstitial fluid, and increases blood flow. This decreases bacterial growth and increases cell proliferation.

questions.text: Dystrophin protein is absent completely in which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Dystrophin protein (a sarcolemmal protein), is absent in patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) due to a mutation in the dystrophin gene. Lack of dystrophin leads to cellular instability, which leads to progressive leakage of intracellular components.

Dystrophin connects actin filaments to the transmembrane protein β-dystroglycan in the sarcolemma by the smaller proteins syntrophins in the cytoplasm.

Duchenne muscular dystrophy is the most common hereditary neuromuscular disease. It is an X-linked recessive disorder, and the causative gene is located at Xp21.

  • Clinical features: Progressive weakness with developmental delay occurs. Pseudohypertrophy of calves and wasting of thigh muscles are seen. Trendelenburg gait or hip waddle is characteristic.
    Gower’s sign: Indicates weakness of proximal muscles: The patient has to use hands and arms to "walk up" their own body from a squatting position.
  • Diagnosis: Elevated serum creatine kinase levels. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) analysis for the dystrophin gene. If PCR is normal, but clinical suspicion is high, muscle biopsy with dystrophin immunocytochemistry is done.
  • Treatment: Treatment of cardiac decompensation, nutritional management, physiotherapy, and glucocorticoids.
  • Prognosis: Death occurs usually at about 18 to 20 years of age due to respiratory failure, intractable heart failure, pneumonia, or aspiration.

Other options:

Option A: Becker's muscular dystrophy(BMD) leads to abnormal dystrophin formation, whereas the dystrophin gene mutation in DMD leads to dystrophin deficiency.

Option C: Myasthenia gravis (MG) is a neuromuscular disorder that is characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles, due to a decrease in the number of available acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at neuromuscular junctions as a result of antibody-mediated autoimmune attack.

Option D: Lambert Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome is a neuromuscular junction disorder associated with the reduced acetylcholine (Ach) release from the presynaptic nerve terminals, despite normal ACh vesicle numbers, ACh presynaptic concentration, and postsynaptic ACh receptors.

questions.text:
A 23 yr old gravida 1, para 0 at 25 weeks gestation, presents with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting for the past 2 days. BP-104/72mm Hg, PR-72bpm. There is generalized edema. Peripheral smear shows hemolysis. Lab values are given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Leukocyte count: 10,500/mm3
Platelet count: 62000/mm3
Hematocrit: 26%
AST: 90 IU/L
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is HELLP syndrome.

The typical presentation of right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, lab findings of thrombocytopenia, low hematocrit, and peripheral smear finding of hemolysis, point towards a diagnosis of  HELLP ( Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelets) syndrome.

Although related to preeclampsia, hypertension and proteinuria may be absent or minimal in HELLP syndrome.

Tennessee criteria used in the diagnosis of HELLP syndrome :

  • Platelet count <1 lakh,
  • AST >70 IU/L,
  • LDH >600 IU/L

Risk factors for HELLP syndrome include

  • Preeclampsia
  • abnormal placentation
  • family history of HELLP syndrome
  • elevated levels of fetal mRNA for FLT l (vascular endothelial growth factor rfi­ receptor 1) and
  • Multiparity
  • Maternal age >34 years
  • European descent
  • History of previous poor pregnancy outcomes

Laboratory evaluation in HELLP:

  • Complete blood cell (CBC) count: Thrombocytopenia, anemia with possible reticulocytosis
  • Coagulation studies: Normal prothrombin time, 50% may have prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time
  • Peripheral smear: Schistocytes, helmet cells, and burr cells secondary to microangiopathic hemolytic anemia
  • Serum aspartate aminotransferase/alanine aminotransferase (AST/ALT) levels: Elevated secondary to liver dysfunction
  • Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level: Elevated secondary to liver dysfunction or hemolysis
  • Elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN)/creatinine with acute renal failure
  • Bilirubin level: Increased secondary to hemolysis
  • Haptoglobin level: Decreased secondary to hemolysis
  • Fibrinogen levels: Low secondary to increased coagulation
  • D-dimer: Increased due to fibrinolysis/DIC

HELLP syndrome may lead to the development of DIC which manifests as increased fibrin split products and decreased fibrinogen levels.

Other options:

Disorder

 AST (SGOT) U/L Bilirubin (mg/dL)
Cholestasis of pregnancy Up to 200 1–5
Acute fatty liver of pregnancy 200–800 4–10
Hepatitis 2000+ 5–20

questions.text: A cricket player was hit on the head with the cricket ball and was fine and then collapsed suddenly. He woke up to play the match brilliantly but was later found unconscious in the dressing room. His CT was taken which is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of lucid interval along with the CT image showing a bi-convex hyperdense lesion is suggestive of extradural hemorrhage.

The patient is initially unconscious from the concussive aspect of the head trauma. The patient then awakens and has a lucid interval, while the hematoma sub-clinically expands. As the volume of the hematoma grows, intracranial pressure (ICP) increases, and the patient rapidly becomes lethargic and herniates.

Extradural hemorrhage is most commonly due to bleeding from the middle meningeal artery. As the dura mater tends to adhere to the skull, the hematoma collecting between the skull and this dura is seen on CT sections as a biconvex dense area immediately beneath the skull vault, convex towards both the brain and the vault. They tend not to cross the suture lines.

The temporoparietal convexity is the most common site. The hematoma usually lies beneath a fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone. The underlying brain is displaced but often appears intrinsically normal.

Related Pearl: Intracranial haemorrhage

questions.text:
Which of the following are storage symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia?
  1. Urgency
  2. Enuresis
  3. Hesitancy
  4. Frequency
  5. Dribbling
questions.solution:
Urgency, enuresis and frequency are storage symptoms.

Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) can be classified as:

Storage Voiding
  • Frequency (earliest symptom in BPH)
  • Nocturia
  • Urgency
  • Urge incontinence
  • Nocturnal incontinence (enuresis)
  • Hesitancy
  • Poor flow
  • Intermittent stream
  • Dribbling
  • Sensation of poor bladder emptying
  • Episodes of near retention

 

Storage symptoms are seen in conditions where the bladder is irritated. Voiding symptoms are common in conditions causing bladder outlet obstruction. In benign prostatic hyperplasia, both storage and voiding symptoms are present.

questions.text: A newborn baby presents with irritability and cyanosis which subsides on crying. On examination, you are unable to pass a nasogastric tube and no mist formation is noted on the laryngeal mirror test. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of choanal atresia, the best next step would be to provide an oropharyngeal airway.

Choanal atresia is the persistence of the bucconasal membrane, unilateral is more common and may remain undiagnosed until adult life, bilateral atresia will present as a respiratory obstruction in the newborn. The initial clinical evaluation consists of placing a large laryngeal mirror under each nostril and checking for fogging, this is known as the laryngeal mirror test.

Diagnosis can be made by:

  • Presence of mucoid discharge in the nose
  • Absence of air bubbles in the nasal discharge
  • Failure to pass a catheter from the nose to the pharynx
  • Putting methylene blue dye into the nose and checking its passage to the pharynx
  • Putting a radio-opaque dye into the nose and taking a lateral radiograph
  • CT in the axial plane 

Management: In bilateral atresia, emergency treatment is to provide an airway, which is done by McGovern's technique- (a feeding tube with a large hole that provides a good oral airway), this removes the need for tracheostomy. Definitive treatment is correcting the atresia either by transpalatal or transnasal approach, which is usually done at one and a half years of age.

Related Pearl: Choanal atresia

  • It is due to the persistence of bucconasal membrane which separates primitive oropharynx from the primitive nasopharynx
  • Unilateral > bilateral
  • 30% of cases are bony and 70% are mixed
  • Unilateral cases may be asymptomatic and present in adult life
  • Bilateral cases are life-threatening and present with respiratory distress
  • Associated with CHARGE syndrome
    • C- Coloboma of the eye
    • H- Heart defects
    • A- Atresia of choana
    • R- Retarded growth and development
    • G- Genital anomalies
    • E- Ear anomalies and hearing loss.
  • CT scan is the best investigation

Image: Membranous, bilateral choanal atresia in a newborn

 

 

  • McGoverns technique- A feeding nipple with a large hole provides a good oral airway
  • Definitive treatment consists of correction of atresia by a trans-nasal or trans-palatal approach.

questions.text: Cleft lip results from failure of fusion of ___

choices.text: Lateral nasal prominence and maxillary prominence
Lateral nasal prominence and mandibular prominence
Medial nasal prominence and maxillary prominence
Medial nasal prominence and mandibular prominence

questions.solution:
Cleft lip is due to failure of fusion between the medial nasal prominence and maxillary prominence.

Various defects of fusion of prominences in the face region are as follows:

  • Cleft lip is due to the failure of the fusion of maxillary prominence with medial nasal prominence. It can be unilateral or bilateral. It can vary in severity from a small notch in the upper lip to a double cleft extending into both the nostrils. There is also associated underdevelopment of the part of the maxilla that bears the incisors.
  • Median (midline) cleft lip is a rare defect occurring due to failure of fusion of the two medial nasal prominences in the midline.
  • Oblique facial cleft is caused by the failure of the maxillary prominence to fuse with the lateral nasal prominence along the line of the nasolacrimal groove. The nasolacrimal duct is exposed to the surface in these cases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents to you with complaints of dryness in the mouth and eyes. Serum testing reveals positive anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies. The test shown in the image below was positive with a score of < 5 mm in 5 minutes without anesthesia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The test shown above is Schirmer's test and the likely diagnosis is Sjögren's syndrome. 

Sjögren's syndrome is an autoimmune disorder that involves lymphocytic infiltration of the exocrine glands. This manifests as xerostomia (dry mouth) and keratoconjunctivitis sicca (dry eyes). It is associated with autoantibodies anti-Ro/SS-A and anti-La/SS-B.

Keratoconjunctivitis sicca can be diagnosed by Schirmer's test. This test measures the quantity of tears produced. Two marked strips of paper are placed between the globe and the lower eyelid and the patient is instructed to close their eyes for 5 minutes. The tears produced spread along the paper by capillary action. The distance is measured. A score of more than 10 mm is considered to be normal while that of less than 5 mm is considered deficient. 

A number of other systems can be involved as well. For example, atrophic gastritis, esophageal mucosal atrophy, and vaginal dryness. Extraglandular or systemic manifestations can also be present. These manifest as fatigue, arthritis, Raynaud's phenomenon, and myalgia. 

Diagnosis of primary Sjögren's syndrome requires the following: 

  • Eye and/or mouth dryness
  • Eye tests disclose keratoconjunctivitis sicca
  • Mouth evaluation reveals dry oral mucosa and/or
  • Presence of anti-Ro or anti-La autoantibodies

A labial (lip) biopsy is a must to confirm the diagnosis and determine the prognosis. 

Treatment of Sjögren's syndrome is directed at treating the symptoms and complications. Artificial tears can be used for dry eyes and propionic acid gel for vaginal dryness. Pilocarpine can help increase oral secretions and hydroxychloroquine can be used to treat arthritis. 

Related Pearl: Extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome

The extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome are as follows:

  • Non-specific
    • Arthralgia or arthritis - It is the most common extraglandular manifestation. It is usually non-erosive and leads to Jacoud’s arthropathy
    • Raynaud’s phenomenon
  • Accumulation of peri-epithelial lymphocytes
    • Interstitial lung disease - Most common type is non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
    • Renal tubular acidosis - Distal (type 1) RTA
    • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Immune complex-mediated
    • Small vessel vasculitis - Presents as cutaneous palpable purpura
    • Glomerulonephritis with cryoglobulinemia
    • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Lymphoma
    • Extranodal marginal zone B cell lymphoma of mucosal-associated lymphoid tissue (MALToma).

questions.text: A young male patient presents with ptosis which reportedly worsens in the evening and improves in the morning. He also complains of excessive fatiguability towards the end of the day which improves with rest. Placing an ice pack over his eyes significantly decreases the ptosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical picture, myasthenia gravis is the most likely diagnosis. This patient has symptoms of ptosis, progressive weakness, and excessive fatiguability which improves with rest. 

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular junction disorder that is characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles. It is due to the autoantibody-mediated destruction of the acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at the post-synaptic membrane. This consequentially leads to a decreased transmission at the neuromuscular junction. Failure of transmission results in muscle weakness.

Females are more commonly affected than males and the disease tends to occur in middle age.

Clinical features of myasthenia gravis:

  • Muscle weakness and fatiguability increase with repeated use or late in the day and may improve following rest or sleep. Limb weakness is proximal and asymmetrical
  • Cranial muscles particularly the lids and extraocular muscles are involved early in the course - diplopia, ptosis
  • Facial weakness - snarling expression on smiling
  • Weakness in chewing
  • Speech with nasal timbre due to the weakness of the palate and tongue
  • Difficulty in swallowing
  • Deep tendon reflexes are intact
  • Myasthenic crisis - acute exacerbation of muscle weakness especially intercostal and diaphragmatic muscles resulting in ventilatory failure. It is most commonly due to infection and anticholinesterase medication overuse.

Myasthenia gravis is associated with thymoma and other autoimmune diseases such as Hashimoto's thyroiditis, Grave's disease, neuromyelitis optics, systemic lupus erythematosus, etc.

Diagnosis:

  • Ice-pack test - application of ice pack over the eyes improves ptosis (decreases activity of acetylcholinesterase, this increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft and increases transmission)
  • Antibodies associated with myasthenia gravis: Anti-AChR antibodies, Anti-MuSK antibodies, Anti-LRP4 antibodies
  • Repetitive nerve stimulation test shows a decremental response.
  • Edrophonium chloride or Tensilon test - improvement of symptoms occurs on injecting edrophonium. Edrophonium is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor. This increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft and improves transmission.

Treatment:

  • Anticholinesterase drugs - Pyridostigmine.
  • Thymectomy.
  • Immunosuppression therapy with glucocorticoids, azathioprine, tacrolimus, rituximab, etc.
  • Plasmapheresis and intravenous immunoglobulin.

questions.text: A veterinary surgeon presents with complaints of fever, muscle pain, joint pain, fatigue, and weight loss for the past few weeks. On further inquiry, he says that his fever persists for weeks before it resolves only to be followed by a relapse.  You obtain his blood sample and inoculate it on the medium given below to isolate the suspected organism. Which of the following is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is suggestive of Brucellosis caused by organisms belonging to the Brucella species. The culture medium depicted in the given image is the Castenada biphasic medium. 

Brucella are small, non-motile, aerobic, capnophilic coccobacilli. The most important species that are pathologic to humans are B.melitensis, B. suis, and B.abortus.

Brucellosis is a zoonosis. It is transmitted to humans from contact with or consumption of contaminated products from goats, sheep, cattle, buffaloes, pigs, and other animals.

Once the infection is transmitted, these bacteria resist intracellular digestion and proliferate within the reticuloendothelial system for a long time. This is the reason why brucellosis often becomes chronic and is resistant to simple antimicrobial therapy. The host immune response is mainly cell-mediated involving activated macrophages, helper T-cells, and mediators such as TNF alpha, TNF gamma, IL-1, and IL-12. 

Clinically, patients may present with an acute infection comprised of undulant fever, as in this patient, characterized by a rising and falling fever. They may also have arthralgia, muscular pain, sweating, loss of weight, and appetite. CNS symptoms such as fatigue, irritability, and depression might also occur. Chronic infection tends to be episodic with non-specific symptoms. 

Laboratory diagnosis of brucellosis is important and includes several methods such as- 

  • Polymerase chain reaction is a sensitive and reliable method of detection. 
  • Culture of Brucella species can be done from specimen including blood, bone marrow aspirate, lymph node aspirate, CSF, and urine. Preferred method and medium of culture includes the Castaneda method. It is a biphasic medium. The solid component is the agar slant and the liquid is the broth. The medium is inoculated with the specimen and incubated for four days in an upright position. Serial subcultures can be obtained by slanting the broth over the agar periodically to inoculate new colonies. 
  • Serological methods include standard agglutination test (SAT), complement fixation test, Coomb’s antiglobulin test, and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). Cut-offs for significant titers are variable depending on the endemicity. Endemic areas or history of laboratory exposure require agglutinin titers of 1:320–1:640 or higher and in nonendemic areas, a titer of more than or equal to 1:160 is considered diagnostic.
  • Tests for animals and animal products include tests such as the milk ring tests and Rose Bengal card tests.
    • Milk ring test- A sample of milk is mixed well with hematoxylin stained brucella antigen and incubated. If the sample contains antibodies to brucella antigens, agglutination occurs with the agglutinate rising to the top as a blue ring. If the sample does not contain antibodies to brucella antigens, the whole of the sample is uniformly stained blue. 

Treatment includes antimicrobial therapy with at least two agents for six weeks duration. The preferred combination is IM streptomycin 0.75-1g per day for two to three weeks along with doxycycline 100mg BD for six weeks. 

Prevention of Brucellosis is important by screening and abiding by safety standards in farms and dairy industries, and also by pasteurization of milk and milk products.

questions.text: Which of the following radioisotopes is used in a PET-CT scan?
questions.solution:
18F-FDG is the radioisotope used in a PET-CT scan.

Positron emission tomography - CT (PET-CT):

  • PET imaging is based on the detection of an injected positron-emitting radioactive tracer.
  • It relies on the coincidence detection of the annihilation photons (γ), which are released when a positron combines with an electron.
  • A glucose analog called FDG (fluorodeoxyglucose) is used in PET imaging. FDG is taken up by metabolically active cells, where it undergoes phosphorylation to form FDG-6-phosphate. Unlike glucose, FDG-6-phosphate cannot undergo further metabolism and becomes trapped within the cell. (So, the patient must be fasted for 4-6 hrs prior to imaging).
  • The trapped FDG-6-phosphate is detected by the PET scanner. 
  • Before injecting FDG, the blood glucose level should be measured. It should be < 150 mg/dL. Good blood glucose control is essential as FDG uptake is competitively inhibited by glucose.
  • Imaging is started 60 minutes following FDG injection.

Indications of PET-CT:

  • PET-CT is used in oncology imaging to detect malignant cells as they demonstrate increased glucose metabolism relative to normal tissues.
  • It is indicated for the differentiation of a malignant from a benign lesion.
  • It is indicated in tumor staging and evaluation of tumor recurrence.

Areas of normal physiological uptake in PET CT:

  • Brain tissue
  • Skeletal muscle, especially after strenuous activity, and laryngeal muscles following speech
  • Myocardium
  • Gastrointestinal tract, e.g. intestinal wall
  • Genitourinary tract (FDG is excreted via the renal system and passes into the collecting systems)
  • Brown fat (FDG accumulates here as glucose and ATP are required for heat production)
  • Thymus
  • Bone marrow

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presents with fatigue. She had pallor on physical examination. Lab values are given below. Serum methyl malonyl CoA levels are normal. Which of the following should be administered as a therapy for this patient?

Hemoglobin - 9.8 g/dL

Platelets - 1,80,000/mm3

Leukocyte count - 7800/mm3

MCV - 106 fl
questions.solution:
This patient has megaloblastic anemia (high MCV). This could be due to various causes, commonly Vitamin B12 or folic acid deficiency. The presence of normal methylmalonyl Co-A favors folic acid deficiency. Thus folic acid has to be given as supplements.

Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase is a vitamin B12-dependent enzyme. The activity of methylmalonyl CoA mutase is greatly reduced in vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to an accumulation of methylmalonic acid and its excretion in urine and is also used to differentiate between megaloblastic anemia due to folate and vitamin B12 deficiency.

There are two vitamin B12-dependent enzymes:

  • Methionine synthase (Homocysteine methyltransferase): Catalyzes the conversion of homocysteine to methionine
  • Methylmalonyl CoA mutase: Methylmalonyl CoA, formed as an intermediate in the catabolism of valine, isoleucine and propionyl CoA is converted to succinyl CoA

Vitamin B12 acts as a cofactor of methionine synthase, an enzyme involved in the regeneration of tetrahydrofolate from methyl-tetrahydrofolate. Hence, in vitamin B12 deficiency methyl-tetrahydrofolate accumulates leading to functional folate deficiency known as the folate trap.

The conversion of 5,10-methylene-THF into 5-methyl-THF (methyltetrahydrofolate) is an irreversible process. The major source of tetrahydrofolate for tissues is 5-methyl-THF. The only way to make further use of 5-methyl-THF and to maintain the folate cycle is by the vitamin B12-dependent remethylation of homocysteine to methionine by the methionine synthase enzyme.

Decreased activity of methionine synthase in vitamin B12 deficiency results in the accumulation of methyltetrahydrofolate, which cannot be used, resulting in a folate trap. The folate cycle acts as the link between the functions of folate and vitamin B12, and deficiency of vitamin B12 can cause a functional deficiency of folate.

Causes of megaloblastic anaemia:-

  • Cobalamin deficiency/abnormalities of cobalamin metabolism: Nutritional, Malabsorption, absence of intrinsic factor, total/ partial gastrectomy.
  • Folate deficiency/ abnormalities of folate metabolism.
  • Therapy with antifolate drugs e.g., methotrexate.
  • Independent of cobalamin/folate deficiency:
    • Acute myeloid leukaemia, myelodysplasia.
    • Therapy with drugs interfering with the synthesis of DNA (e.g., cytosine arabinoside, hydroxyurea, 6-mercaptopurine).
    • Orotic aciduria (responds to uridine).

questions.text: A 17-year-old female presents with primary amenorrhea, but she gets abdominal pain every month. On examination, she has normal development of other secondary sexual characteristics, there is an abdominal lump present and on parting the labia a bluish bulge is noted. Considering the suspected diagnosis, what would be the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
A history of primary amenorrhea, cyclical abdominal pain, presence of a palpable abdominal lump, and visualization of a tense bluish bulging membrane on the separation of the labia suggests the diagnosis of imperforate hymen. A simple cruciate incision of the hymen will allow the drainage of menstrual blood.

Cryptomenorrhoea, also known as hematocolpos, is a condition where menstruation occurs but is not visible due to an obstruction of the outflow tract.

The most common cause is an intact (imperforate) hymen or the presence of a vaginal septum.

A vaginal septum is differentiated from the imperforate hymen by a pinkish concave covering in contrast to the bluish convex bulge in the latter.

An ultrasound scan of the pelvis confirms the diagnosis.

Treatment: A simple cruciate incision of the hymen allows the free drainage of the collected menstrual blood, and leads to normal reproductive function, in cases of imperforate hymen.

 

Note:

In the case of a vaginal septum (i.e atresia), more extensive dissection and vaginoplasty are required.

questions.text: Immediately following vaginal delivery, the patient went into a state of shock. On abdominal examination, the fundus of the uterus could not be felt and per vaginal examination revealed no obvious source of bleeding or clots. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of shock immediately after delivery and absent uterine fundus on abdominal examination is suggestive of uterine inversion. 

Uterine inversion is a condition in which the uterus is turned inside out partially or completely. It causes postpartum collapse which is acute in onset and occurs immediately after delivery.

Causes:

  • Spontaneous- Atony with a sharp rise in intra-abdominal pressure
  • Mismanagement of 3rd stage of labor - Delivering a yet-to-be-separated placenta (Creede’s method)
  • Fundal pressure while the uterus is relaxed

Features:

  • Shock appears immediately after delivery. Mainly neurogenic due to tension on the nerves due to stretching of the infundibulopelvic ligament. Haemorrhage after detachment of placenta
  • The degree of shock is out of proportion to the amount of bleeding
  • Per abdomen examination: Fundus of the uterus is not felt. 
  • A pear-shaped mass protrudes outside the vulva

The following steps are done to reposit the inverted uterus.

  • Discontinue uterotonics
  • Administration of IV crystalloids through large-bore IV cannulas to address shock.
  • Repositioning is tried after confirming that the inverted uterus is not firmly retracted or contracted. If the placenta is attached to the uterus, it is never removed before repositioning. The palm and the fingers are used to push up the uterine fundus along the vaginal axis.
  • Administer tocolytics such as terbutaline, magnesium sulphate, and nitroglycerin to relax the uterus for repositioning if the initial attempt has failed.
  • Oxytocin infusion is started and tocolytics are stopped after repositioning. Await spontaneous expulsion of the placenta.
  • The position of the uterus is maintained while applying bimanual compression.
  • Surgical intervention is needed if repositioning fails or can't be done.

questions.text: A child presents to your outpatient department with the findings shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shown is of a malnourished child with a distended abdomen. This is suggestive of kwashiorkor.

Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) characterized by edema and apathy. It usually affects infants and children, most often around the age of weaning till the age of 5. 

Children with kwashiorkor have moon-shaped faces. Edema is most likely to appear first in the feet and then in the lower legs soon developing into generalized edema. Abdominal distension occurs with or without dilated bowel loops and hepatomegaly and fatty infiltrate.

Skin changes occur over the swollen limbs and include dark, crackled peeling patches with pale skin underneath forming patches of hyper and hypopigmentation called flaky paint dermatosis or crazy paving. The skin gets easily infected.

The hair is dull, brittle, sparse, and can easily be pulled out. It may lose its curl. In dark-haired children, the hair may turn pale or reddish. Alternating bands of light and normal color hair may be seen, known as the flag sign. Children are miserable, apathetic, and often refuse to eat. There is marked muscle atrophy and growth retardation.

  • Emaciated and weak appearance
  • Bradycardia, hypotension, and hypothermia
  • Thin, dry skin
  • Shrunken arms, thighs, and buttocks, with redundant skin folds caused by loss of subcutaneous fat
  • Thin, sparse hair that is easily plucked

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common deficiency observed after gastric bypass/bariatric surgery?
questions.solution: Iron deficiency is the most common deficiency observed following gastric bypass or bariatric surgery. Iron is absorbed in the duodenum and proximal jejunum, bypass procedures lead to or exacerbate an existing deficiency by impairing absorption. questions.text: A 28-year-old woman complaints of inability to conceive, dysmenorrhea, and pelvic pain. She has a history of frequent pelvic inflammatory disease. Hysterosalpingogram shows an absence of peritoneal spillage on the right side. Identify the given clinical scenario.

The given clinical scenario is indicative of a tubal block. 

The presenting complaints of tubal block are: 

  • Dysmenorrhea 
  • Pelvic pain 
  • Inability to conceive 
  • Repeated episodes of PID 
  • History of ectopic pregnancy 

Tubal block can be due to:

  • Strictures - fibrotic block
  • Inspissated amorphous material
  • Tubal spasm - This can occur in apprehensive patients. It is prevented by premedication with atropine and analgesia

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is a technique used for visualization of the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes by the injection of a radio-opaque dye, and visualization of the dye by fluoroscopy as it passes through the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes. It is best performed between the end of the menstrual period and ovulation (i.e 9th or 10th day of the cycle). 10-15ml of the dye is injected using a Leech-Wilkinson cannula, Rubin's cannula, or Foley's catheter. If the tubes are patent, the dye will spill out of the tubal Ostia and smear the adjacent bowel.

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal pain and distension. An X-ray was taken which showed dilated bowel loops as given in the image below. Identify the segment involved.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and X-ray suggest intestinal obstruction with involvement of the jejunum. The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae connivente (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel). The gas bubbles trapped between the valvulae connivente give a string of beads appearance/ ladder effect. 

Radiological features of bowel obstruction 

  • Small bowel - The involved dilated segments are straight and most centrally located. 
  • Jejunum - It is characterized by the presence of valvulae connivente with gas bubbles trapped between them. This gives a string of beads/ ladder effect. 
  • Ileum - The distal ileal obstruction is usually featureless. 
  • Caecum - A rounded gas shadow in the right iliac fossa is suggestive of caecal obstruction.
  • Large bowel - The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man has come with complaints of hair loss. Examination findings are given below. The most likely diagnosis in this man is?
questions.solution:
The image above shows circumscribed, hairless, smooth patch. Short, easily extractable broken hairs, known as exclamation mark hairs, are seen at the margins of the bald patch. This is characteristic of alopecia areata.

It is characterized by a circumscribed, smooth patch of hair loss. Exclamation mark hairs are often seen at the margins of the bald patches during active phases of the disease. Follicular orifices may appear as yellow dots on dermoscopy.

Alopecia areata is a chronic, inflammatory, autoimmune disease that causes non-scarring hair loss.

Other options: 

Option A: Tinea capitis (as shown in the images below): The appearance may vary from dull grey, broken‐off hairs with a little scaling to a severe, painful, inflammatory mass covering the entire scalp. Predominantly seen in children, however, adults can also be affected due to infection by T.tonsurans. 

Option B: Kerion (T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes) is a severe inflammatory type that presents with an inflammatory mass with thick crusting and matting of hair with pus and sinus formation.

Option D: Trichotillomania (as shown in the image below) is a psychiatric disorder characterized by com­pulsive hair pulling. There is increased tension prior to the hair-pulling and a relief of tension or gratification after the hair-pulling. It presents as an area of patchy hair loss, often in a bizarre pattern. The hairs are often twisted and broken at various distances from the scalp or may be present as uniform, coarse stubble. The scalp skin appears normal.

questions.text: A factory worker from a plastic pipe factory presented to the OPD with complaints of weight loss and right upper quadrant abdominal pain from the last 6 months. On examination, he had hepatomegaly. Further investigation revealed that most of the liver was replaced by a hemorrhagic tumor with extensive necrosis. What can be the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is angiosarcoma of the liver.

Angiosarcoma of the liver is usually seen in individuals having occupational exposure to agents such as vinyl chloride, arsenic, or thorotrast. The gross specimen of the liver shows greyish-white lesions, with multiple reddish-brown hemorrhagic foci and several blood-filled spaces.

Option A: Cavernous hemangiomas appear as red-blue, soft nodules, usually less than 2 cm in diameter. Their clinical significance is that they might be mistaken radiographically or intraoperatively for metastatic tumors.

Option B: Metastatic carcinoma of the liver has a gross appearance that shows multiple nodular lesions of variable size, replacing much of the normal parenchyma.

Option D: Primary hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has a peak incidence around 20 to 40 years of age and is predominantly seen in men. The gross appearance shows unifocal or multifocal or diffusely infiltrative lesions that are paler than the surrounding tissue. The lesions may be greenish due to the presence of bile. Cirrhosis may be seen in about 50% of the cases. Intrahepatic metastases may be seen.

questions.text: A one-and-a-half-year-old child is brought to the hospital with a history of breathlessness, fever, cough, and cold. On examination, the respiratory rate was 46/min, and there were no chest retractions. Which is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Administer IV antibiotics and refer to higher centre
Administer oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send home

questions.solution:
From the given clinical picture, it can be inferred that the child has pneumonia.
The treatment for pneumonia for a child between 2 months and 5 years of age is: oral amoxicillin and home care advice.

Pneumonia diagnosis is as given in the table below:

Age of child Fast breathing RR
<2 months 60 breaths/min
2-12 months 50 breaths/min

The revised classification of acute respiratory infections is simplified to include only two categories of pneumonia:

  • Pneumonia—with fast breathing and/or chest indrawing, which requires home therapy with oral amoxicillin, and
  • Severe pneumonia—pneumonia with any general danger sign, which requires referral and injectable therapy

Danger signs:

  • Not able to drink
  • Persistent vomiting
  • Convulsions, lethargic or unconscious
  • Stridor in a calm child
  • Severe malnutrition

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient had acute appendicitis 3 days ago and presented to the surgery department with abdominal pain and tenderness. Which of the following incision would be appropriate for this condition?
questions.solution:
McBurney's incision (also called gridiron incision), marked 3 in the image, is popularly used for open appendicectomy. It is an oblique incision (superolateral to inferomedial) passing along McBurney's point. 

The major anterior abdominal incisions have been illustrated below:

  • 1 is Kocher incision - A subcostal incision used to gain access for gall bladder and/or biliary tree pathology.
  • 2 is midline incision - The most common incision for laparotomy. This vertical incision follows the linea alba which is particularly favored in diagnostic laparotomy, as they allow wide access to most of the abdominal cavity.
  • 3 is McBurney's incision (also called gridiron incision) is an oblique incision (superolateral to inferomedial) passing along McBurney's point. It is popularly used for open appendicectomy.
  • 4 is a battle incision a lower right paramedian incision but placed more laterally than the standard paramedian incision. It is suitable for dealing with acute appendicitis and pathologies in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen.
  • 5 is Lanz incision, a transverse or skin crease incision for appendicitis, 2 cm below the umbilicus, centered on the midclavicular–mid-inguinal line. Due to its continuation with Langer’s lines, the Lanz incision produces much more aesthetically pleasing results with reduced scarring.
  • 6 is a paramedian incision - this incision is used to access much of the lateral viscera, such as the kidneys, spleen, and adrenal glands.
  • 7 is transverse incision - A supraumbilical transverse incision offers excellent exposure to the upper abdomen. A transverse incision may be superior to a midline incision in terms of recovery and complications postoperatively.
  • 8 is Rutherford Morrison incision, an oblique muscle cutting incision used for access to the sigmoid colon and pelvis in patients where the midline is scarred due to previous surgery. Rutherford Morison’s incision is useful if the appendix is para- or retrocaecal and fixed. It is essentially an oblique muscle-cutting incision with its lower end over McBurney’s point and extending obliquely upwards and laterally as necessary
  • 9 is Pfannenstiel incision - An infraumbilical transverse incision in the lower abdomen, often used for gynecological and obstetric procedures.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions shown below has a false positive Barr body?
questions.solution:
A person with Klinefelter syndrome has an extra X chromosome and thus there is a false positive Barr body in this patient.

Barr body is the inactivated X chromosome in the cell which is peripherally situated as a darkly stained nodule, chromatin positive, and better seen in the epithelial cell nuclei. Male cells have only one X chromosome and are called chromatin negative as they do not have a Barr body. The total number of Barr bodies is given by the formula (X-1) as the inactivated X chromosome is seen as the Barr body.

Barr bodies are seen in 0-4% of genetic males (46XY) and 20-80% of genetic females (46XX) and the most common sites for sampling for sex chromatin are buccal mucosa, tooth pulp, and hair bulb.

In a normal male, there are no Barr bodies as the genotype is XY. Females are XX and thus have a Barr body in them.

Males with Klinefelter syndrome have XXY genotype and thus have a false positive Barr body while a female with Turner syndrome has XO and has no Barr body usually. Only in rare cases of mosaicism will Turner syndrome patients have a Barr body.
